{{Infobox News event |image= |caption= |date=January 2016 |time= |place= |suspects= |casualties1=Reported deaths: 32 |casualties2=Reported cases: 153 |casualties3= |notes= }}
[[Pneumococcal infection|Pneumococcal meningitis]] cases were recorded in [[Ghana]] in the last quarter of 2015 and an outbreak confirmed by the [[Ministry of Health (Ghana)|ministry of health]] was reported in January 2016. On January 26, 2016, it was reported that 153 people had become infected and 32 had died.<ref name="who">{{cite news | url=http://www.africanews.com/2016/01/25/who-assists-ghana-to-deal-with-meningitis-outbreak/ | title=WHO assists Ghana to deal with meningitis outbreak | work=AfricaNews | date=January 26, 2016 | accessdate=January 26, 2016}}</ref><ref name="infograph">{{cite web | url=http://ghanahealthnest.com/meningitis-disease-outbreak-in-ghana/ | title=Infograph: Pneumococcal Meningitis disease outbreak in Ghana (live blog) | publisher=GhanaHealthNest | date=January 15, 2016 | accessdate=January 26, 2016 | author=Kobby Blay}}</ref><ref name="fulton">{{cite news | url=http://www.newsfultoncounty.com/health/news/2025049-meningitis-outbreak-in-ghana-claims-22-lives | title=Meningitis outbreak in Ghana claims 22 lives | date=January 20, 2016 | accessdate=January 26, 2016 | author=Kristoff Saunders}}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}} {{Ghana-stub}} {{Africa-hist-stub}} [[Category:Medical outbreaks in Ghana]] [[Category:2016 in Ghana]] [[Category:Meningitis]]

The [http://www.ucdp.uu.se/gpdatabase/peace/Lib%2019950819.pdf '''Abuja Agreement'''] was a peace treaty signed on 19 August 1995 in an attempt to secure peace from [[National Patriotic Front of Liberia]] leader, [[Charles G. Taylor|Charles Taylor]] in the [[First Liberian Civil War]]. The agreement was another in a list of treaties attempting to bring peace to [[Liberia]], being preceded by the [[Cotonou Accord]] on 25 July 1993, the [[Akosombo Agreement]] on 12 August 1994, and its Accra Clarification.
The agreement set up a Council of State of Liberia, which was to consist of a chair, and five members: [[Charles Taylor (Liberian politician)|Charles Taylor]], LTG. [[G. V. Kromah]] ([[United Liberation Movement of Liberia for Democracy]]), Dr. [[George Boley]] Sr. (LNC), [[Oscar Jaryee Quiah]] ([[Liberian National Conference]]), and Chief [[Tamba Tailor]]. According to the accords, the first holder of the rotating chairmanship was to be [[Wilton G. S. Sankawulo]], but the position was actually first held by [[David D. Kpormakor]]. The council's third and final chair, [[Ruth Perry]], handed power to Taylor following elections in July 1997.
==External links== *[http://peacemaker.un.org/node/309 Text of the Abuja Accord] *[http://peacemaker.un.org/document-search?keys=&field_padate_value%5Bvalue%5D%5Bdate%5D=&field_pacountry_tid=liberia&field_paconflict_tid%5B%5D=1 Text of all peace accords for Liberia]
[[Category:Peace treaties]] [[Category:1995 in Liberia]] [[Category:Treaties concluded in 1995]] [[Category:Treaties of Liberia]] [[Category:History of Liberia]]

{{Infobox radio station | name = B5 aktuell | image = B5 aktuell (2007).svg | image_size = <!-- optional when used with image parameter, specifies image size --> | alt = <!-- optional when used with image parameter, specifies image alternate (alt) text --> | caption = <!-- optional when used with image parameter, specifies image caption --> | city = | area = [[Bavaria]] | branding = | slogan = | frequency = <!-- {{Frequency|NNN|XHz}} --> | translator = | repeater = | airdate = {{Start date|1991|5|6|df=yes}} | last airdate = <!-- for defunct stations --> | format = | language = [[German language|German]] | power = | erp = | haat = | class = | facility_id = | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|}} --> | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | former_frequencies = | affiliations = | operator = [[Bayerischer Rundfunk]] (BR) | owner = | licensee = | sister_stations = | webcast = <!-- [URL Listen Live] --> | website = {{URL|b5aktuell.de}} }}
'''B5 aktuell''' is a German, public [[radio station]] owned and operated by the [[Bayerischer Rundfunk]] (BR). == History == B5 aktuell launched on May 6, 1991 at 6:00am and took over the additional frequency of BR4, over which until then the evening ARD-Gastarbeitersendungen broadcasts, as well as some special parliamentary debates or other events were adopted. Model was the French news channel France Info of Radio France. Later, other stations in Germany took over the concept of B5 aktuell, such as MDR Info (1992), Inforadio from RBB (1995), NDR Info (1998), hr-info (2004), SWRinfo (2012) and DRS 4 News in Switzerland (2007). As one of the first ARD radio stations on the Internet B5 has been online since November 1995. On September 8, 2011 B5 was recently awarded the German Radio Prize in the "Best News Format" category. == Contents == Main features of the program structure on the air are the 15-minute rolling news blocks. The information blocks on the hour and half hour are designed for a length of 8 minutes and are presented by editors. In these info-blocks there are also correspondent contributions and o-tones. At XY: 15 and XY: 45 clock come five-minute news without recordings, read by newscasters. The last minutes of the block are filled with various in-depth contributions to certain topics after a program clock, then at XY: 08 a block with news only from Bavaria and XY: 55 a block with sports news aired. A stock market update is read every 2 blocks, and local traffic and weather news is read in every block.
B5 currently also transmits selected sports events, such as International matches of the national football team, the Champions League (here the games of FC Bayern Munich) and the ARD Bundesliga conference live, sometimes in full length.
To expand the offer of live broadcasts, launched on 8 October 2007, B5 plus was launched to provide additional sporting events and live scores from the German Bundestag and the Bavarian state parliament transfers, alongside extended breaking news coverage. At all other times, B5 plus relays B5 aktuell. == Listening figures and broadcasts == B5 aktuell currently broadcasts from 6am to midnight (in the remaining time the ARD-Infonacht is taken over) and is transmitted in Bavaria nationwide over ultra short wave VHF and via DAB + in the channel 11D. In Südtirol, the broadcaster is broadcast by the broadcaster Rundfunk-Anstalt Südtirol in the standard DAB +. Europe-wide B5 is currently receivable via DVB-S and DVB-C. Worldwide, the program can be heard via livestream. In addition, there are individual programs as a podcast. The shortwave broadcasting (digital on 6085 kHz in DRM mode since May 2, 2005) on the transmitter Ismaning was set on October 1, 2010.
The current RDS PTY code for B5 is 02 ("Current Affairs") because the vast majority of the broadcasting time are backgrounds, debates, analyzes, and the like. However, it will be permanently marked with RDS PTY code 01 ("News", Messages) sent; a nationwide exception. In particular, car radios often offer the possibility to emphasize messages in addition to traffic using dynamic PTY: for example, transmits the German radio basically code 03 ("Information"), only during the news 01, however, which allows radios to temporarily change channels and adjust the volume. Due to the continuous transmission of the message code at B5 aktuell, there could be an effect known as station-kidnapping, because the radio remains on the transmitter until the message function of the device is deactivated or the transmission area is left again.
B5 aktuell currently has around 590,000 listeners in Bavaria every day, which corresponds to a market share of 5.3%. In addition, there are around 40,000 in other states.

revision.text:
[[File:Rolako ploughing.jpg|thumb|250px|Agriculture is a major employer of child labour in Africa. Ploughing (above), fertilizer, pesticide application and harvesting routinely involve children with their families.]]'''Child labour in Africa''' is generally defined based on two factors: type of work and minimum appropriate age of the work<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=Edmonds|first=Eric V.|title=Chapter 57 Child Labor|date=2007|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/s1573-4471(07)04057-0|work=Handbook of Development Economics|pages=3607–3709|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=9780444531001|access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>. If a child is involved in an activity that is harmful to his/her physical and mental development, he/she is generally considered as a child labourer. That is, Any work that is mentally, physically, socially or morally dangerous and harmful to children, and interferes with their schooling by depriving them of the opportunity to attend school or requiring them to attempt to combine school attendance with excessively long and heavy work<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/ipec/facts/lang--en/index.htm|title=What is child labour (IPEC)|website=www.ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>. Appropriate minimum age for each work depends on the effects of the work on the physical health and mental development of children. ILO Convention No. 138 suggests the following minimum age for admission to employment under which, if a child works, he/she is considered as a child laborer: 18 years old for [https://www.ilo.org/ipec/facts/WorstFormsofChildLabour/Hazardouschildlabour/lang--en/index.htm hazardous works] (Any work that jeopardizes children’s physical, mental or moral health), and 13-15 years old for light works (any work that does not threaten children's health and safety, or prevent them from schooling or vocational orientation and training), although 12-14 years old may be permitted for light works under strict conditions in very poor countries<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/ipec/facts/ILOconventionsonchildlabour/lang--en/index.htm|title=ILO Conventions and Recommendations on child labour (IPEC)|website=www.ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>. Another definition proposed by ILO’s Statistical Information and Monitoring Program on Child Labor (SIMPOC) defines a child as a child labourer if he/she is involved in an economic activity, and is under 12 years old and works one or more hours per week, or is 14 years old or under and works at least 14 hours per week, or is 14 years old or under and works at least one hour per week in activities that are hazardous, or is 17 or under and works in an “[https://www.ilo.org/ipec/facts/WorstFormsofChildLabour/lang--en/index.htm unconditional worst form of child labor]” (prostitution, children in bondage or forced labor, armed conflict, trafficked children, pornography, and other illicit activities)<ref>{{Cite book|title=Every Child Counts: New Global Estimates on Child Labour|last=|first=|publisher=International Labour Office|year=2002|isbn=92-2-113113-0|location=Geneva|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":0" />.
[[Africa]] has the world's highest incidence rates of [[child labour]]. A report by the United Nations' International Labour Organization reveals that in 2016 nearly 1 out of every 5 children partakes in child labor.<ref>https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/11/17/564820082/new-numbers-on-child-labor-are-not-encouraging</ref> The problem is severe in [[Sub-Saharan Africa|sub-saharan Africa]] where more than 40% of all children aged 5–14 labour for survival, or about 48 million children.<ref name="iloafr">{{cite web|title=Child labour in Africa|publisher=ILO|year=2010|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_norm/---declaration/documents/publication/wcms_decl_fs_37_en.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=THE STATE OF THE WORLD’S CHILDREN - 2011|publisher=UNICEF|year=2012|url=http://www.unicef.org/sowc2011/pdfs/SOWC-2011-Main-Report_EN_02092011.pdf}}</ref>
Although [[poverty]] is generally considered as the primary cause of child labour in Africa<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ernest Harsch|title=Child labour rooted in Africa's poverty|journal=Africa Recovery|volume=15|number=3|date=October 2001|pages=14–15|url=https://www.un.org/en/africarenewal/vol15no3/153chil4.htm}}</ref>, recent studies show that the relationship between child labour and poverty is not as simple as a downward linear relationship. For example, Oryoie, Alwang, and Tideman (2017)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Oryoie|first=Ali Reza|last2=Alwang|first2=Jeffrey|last3=Tideman|first3=Nicolaus|date=2017|title=Child Labor and Household Land Holding: Theory and Empirical Evidence from Zimbabwe|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.worlddev.2017.07.025|journal=World Development|volume=100|pages=45–58|doi=|issn=0305-750X|via=}}</ref> show that child labour generally decreases as per capita land holding (as an indicator of a household's wealth in rural areas) increases, but there can be an upward bump in the relationship between child labour and landholding near the middle of the range of land per capita. In addition to poverty, Lack of resources, together with other factors such as credit constraints, income shocks, school quality, and parental attitudes toward education are all associated with child labour<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ersado|first=Lire|date=2005|title=Child Labor and Schooling Decisions in Urban and Rural Areas: Comparative Evidence from Nepal, Peru, and Zimbabwe|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.worlddev.2004.09.009|journal=World Development|volume=33|issue=3|pages=455–480|doi=|issn=0305-750X|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Oryoie|first=Ali Reza|last2=Alwang|first2=Jeffrey|date=2018|title=School attendance and economic shocks: Evidence from rural Zimbabwe|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0376835x.2018.1496814|journal=Development Southern Africa|volume=|pages=1–12|doi=10.1080/0376835x.2018.1496814|issn=0376-835X|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weir|first=S.|date=2010|title=Parental Attitudes and Demand for Schooling in Ethiopia|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/jae/ejq034|journal=Journal of African Economies|volume=20|issue=1|pages=90–110|doi=10.1093/jae/ejq034|issn=0963-8024|via=}}</ref>.
The [[International Labour Organization]] estimates that agriculture is the largest employer of child labour in Africa. Vast majority are unpaid family workers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facts on Child Labor - 2010|publisher=ILO, Geneva|year=2011|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/@dgreports/@dcomm/documents/publication/wcms_126685.pdf}}</ref>
==Cultural history== [[File:Kamerun children weaving cloth 2.jpg|thumb|250px|Africa has a long history of child labour. Above, colonial [[Cameroon]] children weaving in 1919.]] Children in Africa have worked in farms and at home over a long history. This is not unique to Africa; large number of children have worked in agriculture and domestic situations in America, Europe and every other human society, throughout history, prior to 1950s. Scholars suggest that this work, specially in rural areas, was a form of schooling and vocational education, where children learned the arts and skills from their parents, and as adults continued to work in the same hereditary occupation. Bass claims this is particularly true in the African context.<ref name=bass04>{{cite book|title=Child Labor in Sub-Saharan Africa|author=Loretta Bass|year=2004|isbn=978-1588262868|pages=30–43|publisher=Lynne Rienner Publications}}</ref><ref name=hh09>{{cite book|title=The World of Child Labor|author=Beverly Grier (Ed: Hugh Hindman)|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|year=2009|pages=173–177|isbn=978-0-7656-1707-1}}</ref>
Africa is a highly diverse and culturally continent. In parts of this continent, farming societies adhere to a system of patrilineal lineages and clans. The young train with the adults. The family and kinsfolk provide a cultural routine that help children learn useful practical skills and enables these societies to provide for itself in the next generation. Historically, there were no formal schools, instead, children were informally schooled by working informally with their family and kin from a very early age. Child labor in Africa, as in other parts of the world, was also viewed as a way to instill a sense of responsibility and a way of life in children particularly in rural, subsistence agricultural communities. In rural ''Pare'' people of northern Tanzania, for example, five-year-olds would assist adults in tending crops, nine-year-olds help carry fodder for animals and responsibilities scaled with age.<ref name=bass04/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Introduction - Child Labour|author=Cindi Katz|journal=Anthropology of Work Review|volume=17|issue=1–2|pages=3–8|date=June–September 1996|doi=10.1525/awr.1996.17.1-2.3}}</ref> [[File:ThiMil FillBer.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Berber people|Berber]] shepherd girl in the [[Atlas Mountains]] of [[Morocco]].]] In northern parts of sub-Saharan Africa, Islam is a major influence. Begging and child labour was considered as a service in exchange for quranic education, and in some cases continues to this day.<ref>{{cite web|title=Talibes in Senegal|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=April 15, 2010|url=https://www.hrw.org/features/talib-s-senegal}}</ref> These children aged 7–13, for example, were called ''almudos'' in [[Gambia]], or ''talibés'' in [[Senegal]]. The parents placed their children with ''[[marabout]]'' or ''serin'', a cleric or quranic teacher. Here, they would split their time between begging and studying the Quran. This practice fit with one of the five pillars of Islam, the responsibility to engage in ''zakat'', or almsgiving.<ref>{{cite book|author=Helen Boyle|title=Quranic Schools: Agents of Preservation & Change|publisher=Routledge|year=2004|isbn=978-0415946353}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Njàngaan: The Daily Regime of Quranic Students in Twentieth-Century Senegal|author=Rudolph T. Ware III|journal=The International Journal of African Historical Studies|volume=37|number=3|year=2004|pages=515–538|jstor=4129043}}</ref>
The growth of colonial rule in Africa, from 1650 to 1950, by powers such as Britain, France, Belgium, Germany and Netherlands encouraged and continued the practice of child labour. Colonial administrators preferred Africa's traditional kin-ordered modes of production, that is hiring a household for work not just the adults. Millions of children worked in colonial agricultural plantations, mines and domestic service industries.<ref name=bass04/><ref name=hh09/> Children in these colonies between the ages of 5-14 were hired as apprentice ''without'' pay in exchange for learning a craft. Colonial British laws, for example, offered the native people ownership to some of the native land in exchange for making labor of wife and children available to colonial government's needs such as in farms and as ''picannins''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Masters, Servants, and Magistrates in Britain and the Empire, 1562-1955 (Studies in Legal History)|author=Douglas Hay|year=2007|isbn=978-0807828779|pages=38–46|publisher= University of North Carolina Press}}</ref> [[File:Shoe Shine Boy, Ethiopia (8198535107).jpg|thumb|right|A boy shoeshiner in [[Gondar]], [[Ethiopia]].]] Child labour was also encouraged by new tax laws. [[British Empire|British]] and [[French colonial empire|French]] colonial empires introduced new taxes to help pay for the local colonial government expenses. One of these, called the Head Tax, imposed a tax payable by every person, in some cases as young as 8 year old. Regional populations rebelled against such taxes, hid their children, and in most part had to ensure their children were involved in economic activity to pay such taxes and pay their living expenses.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Child labor in the Gold Coast: the economics of work, education and the family in late-colonial Africa, c.1940-57|url=http://eprints.soas.ac.uk/11595/1/Jack_Lord%2C_Child_Labor_in_the_Gold_Coast.pdf|author=Jack Lord|journal=The Journal of the History of Childhood and Youth|volume=4|issue=1|year=2011|pages=88–115|doi=10.1353/hcy.2011.0005}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Invisible Hands: Child Labor and the State in Colonial Zimbabwe by Beverly Grier (a review)|author=Karen Wells|journal=The Journal of the History of Childhood and Youth|volume=1|number=3|date=Fall 2008|pages=481–483 |doi= 10.1353/hcy.0.0025}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Head Tax, Social Structure and Rural Incomes in Cameroun, 1922-1937|author=Jane Guyer|journal=Cahiers d'Études Africaines|volume=20|issue=79|year=1980|pages=305–329|doi=10.3406/cea.1980.2338}}</ref> Christian mission schools in Africa stretching from Zambia to Nigeria too required work from children, and in exchange provided religious education, not [[secular education]].<ref name=bass04/>
In late colonial period, colonial governments attempted to run schools and educate children in parts of Africa. These effort were generally unsuccessful both in terms of enrollment and impact. Few children enrolled. Even when children enrolled, it did not necessarily mean regular attendance. Chronic absenteeism, or children dropped out of the schools to instead “go to sea with the fishermen.” Jack Lord claims in his reviews of scholarly papers of African colonial history, that late colonial era experience suggests children and families made decisions based on complex combination of economic factors such as household income, state of the family, and cultural factors that considered working with families as a form of education and a form of developing social and human capital.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Child labor in the Gold Coast: the economics of work, education and the family in late-colonial Africa, c.1940-57|year=2011|journal=The Journal of the History of Childhood and Youth|volume=4|issue=1|pages= 88–115|url=http://eprints.soas.ac.uk/11595/1/Jack_Lord%2C_Child_Labor_in_the_Gold_Coast.pdf|doi=10.1353/hcy.2011.0005}}</ref>
==Contemporary child labour== [[File:Mining diggerboys.jpg|thumb|upright|Child labour is common in informal mining industry of Africa. Above, children engaged in diamond mining in [[Sierra Leone]].]] Agriculture alone employs more than 30% of all African children aged 10–14.<ref name=iloafr/> Informal economy such as small scale artisanal mines is another significant employer of child labour.
===Burkina Faso=== According to Burkina Faso’s United States Department of Labor<ref>{{cite web|title=United States Department of Labor - Burkina Faso Reports Child Labor Findings|year=2012|url=https://www.dol.gov/ilab/reports/child-labor/findings/2012TDA/burkinafaso.pdf}}</ref> in 2012, 37.8% of children in Burkina Faso, between the ages of 5-14 years, were working in granite quarries and gold mines. These children have worked 6 to 7 days a week for up to 14 hours per day. Payment is in the form of food to eat and a place to sleep. Since that time, the Government has adopted a National Action Plan, and in collaboration with Interpol, have since have rescued many children from child trafficking.
Christian Children's Fund of Canada (CCFC) has partnered with EDUCO, a fellow member of the [[ChildFund Alliance]], to implement a European Union-funded project in north Burkina to prevent children from working in mines.<ref>{{cite web|title=Keeping Children Safe from Working in Gold Mines, 2017|publisher=Christian Children’s Fund of Canada|url=https://www.ccfcanada.ca/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=823&Itemid=222}}</ref>
===Congo=== In 2008, Bloomberg claimed child labour in copper and cobalt mines of [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]] that supplied Chinese companies. The children dig the ore by hand, carry sacks of ores on their backs, and these are then purchased by these companies. Over 60 of [[Katanga Province|Katanga's]] 75 processing plants are owned by Chinese companies and 90 percent of the region's minerals go to China.<ref>{{cite news|title=China Lets Child Workers Die Digging in Congo Mines for Copper|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=July 22, 2008|author1=Simon Clark |author2=Michael Smith |author3=Franz Wild |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aW8xVLQ4Xhr8}}</ref> An African NGO report claimed 80,000 child labourers under the age of 15, or about 40% of all miners, were supplying ore to Chinese companies in this African region.<ref>{{cite web| title=Strengthening the Civil society Perspective: China’s African impact| pages=9–15| author=Stephen Marks| year=2010| publisher=Fahamu| url=http://www.fahamu.org/downloads/strengthening_the_civil_society_perspective.pdf| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104005117/http://www.fahamu.org/downloads/strengthening_the_civil_society_perspective.pdf| archivedate=2011-01-04| df=}}</ref>
BBC, in 2012, accused [[Glencore]] of using child labour in its mining and smelting operations of Africa. Glencore denied it used child labour, and said it has strict policy of not using child labour. Glencore claimed being aware of child miners who it claimed were part of a group of artisanal miners. They had without authorisation raided Glencore's concession since 2010, and the company claimed it has been pleading with the government to remove the artisanal miners from its concession.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mining giant Glencore accused in child labour and acid dumping row|author=John Sweeney|publisher=The Guardian|date=14 April 2012|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2012/apr/14/glencore-child-labour-acid-dumping-row}}</ref>
About 4.7 million children aged 5–14 work in Congo. In addition to copper mines, children with their families participate in artisanal mining of [[cobalt]], [[wolframite]], [[cassiterite]], [[columbite-tantalite]], [[gold]], diamonds. Many of these use hammers to break free the ore, pour harsh chemicals with no protective equipment, and manually transport rocks from deep pit or open pit mines. Children also work in agriculture and continue to be recruited as child soldiers for Congolese National Army and various rebel groups. Child labour is commonly visible on the streets of Kinshasa region.<ref name=dol10/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Association of Trauma and PTSD Symptoms With Openness to Reconciliation and Feelings of Revenge Among Former Ugandan and Congolese Child Soldiers|author1=Christophe Pierre Bayer |author2=Fionna Klasen |author3=Hubertus Adam |journal=JAMA|year=2007|volume=298|number=5|pages=555–559|doi=10.1001/jama.298.5.555 |pmid=17666676}}</ref>
===Ghana=== The 2010 [[United States Department of Labor]] estimated over 2.7 million child labourers in [[Ghana]], or about 43% of all children aged 5–14. Agriculture, fishing and artisan mining were the largest employers.<ref name=dol10/>
Children in Accra and Ashanti regions were common in domestic services. Child porters, locally called ''kayaye'', work in urban areas and some of them are as young as 6 years.
In southern Volta region, children work in [[Ritual servitude|religious servitude]] for a period ranging between few months to three years. They are known as ''trokosi'' (literally: wife of a god), ''fiashidi '', or ''vudusi''. This practice requires young girls to work and serve the religious order, in order to atone for family members’ alleged sins or as an offering for the family's good fortune. This practice is claimed to be also present in neighboring countries, even though it has been outlawed and imposes prison term under the laws of Ghana and neighboring countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pan-African Issues in Crime and Justice (Editors: Anita Kalunta-Crumpton, Biko Agozino) - See Chapter 2|author=Robert Kwame Ameh|publisher=Ashgate|year=2004|isbn=978-0754618829}}</ref>
In 2013, statistics on children's work have not changed much and according to the DOL's ''Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor'' in Ghana, the majority of working children engage in hazardous activities like pesticide spraying in the production of cocoa, fishing and gold mining.<ref>[http://www.dol.gov/ilab/reports/child-labor/ghana.htm Ghana, 2013 Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor]</ref> The Department's 2014 ''[[List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor]]'' includes fish and [[tilapia]] in particular, cocoa and gold as goods produced in such working conditions in Ghana.
===Kenya=== [[File:Young Maasai herder Kenya, 1979.jpg|thumb|250px|A child as [[Maasai people|Maasai]] herder in [[Kenya]].]] Suda, in 2001, estimated that [[Kenya]] had 3 million children working in intolerable conditions and who were visible. The number of invisible child workers, claims Suda, were much larger. The visible child labour in Kenya were engaged in agriculture, tourism industry, quarries and mines, pastoral labour, mining, garbage collection, fishing industry, and the transport sector where they move from place to place as '' "Matatu" touts''.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Invisible Child Worker in Kenya: The Intersection of Poverty, Legislation and Culture|author=Collette Suda|journal=Nordic Journal of African Studies|volume=10|number=2|pages=163–175|year=2001|url=http://www.njas.helsinki.fi/pdf-files/vol10num2/suda.pdf}}</ref>
The government of Kenya estimates there are 8.9 million children aged 5–13 who work, most of whom miss schooling. Agriculture is a major employer; of all labourers employed in coffee plantations, for example, 30% are children younger than age 27.
United Nations, in its country profile report for Kenya in 2009, estimated about one third of all children aged 5–14 were working. Agriculture and fishing were the largest employers, with former accounting for roughly 79% of child labour.<ref>{{cite web|title=Country profile report - Kenya|year=2009|publisher=United Nations|url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/pdfid/4d4a6806d.pdf}}</ref>
The United States Department of Labor estimated, in its 2010 report, about 32% of all Kenyan children aged 5–14 work, or over 2.9 million. Agriculture and fishing are the predominant employers. The informal sectors witnessing the worst form of child labour include sugarcane plantations, pastoral ranches, tea, coffee, miraa (a stimulant plant), rice, sisal, tobacco, tilapia and sardines fishing. Other economic activities of children in Kenya include scavenging dumpsites, collecting and selling scrap materials, glass and metal, street vending, herding and begging. Forced exploitation of children in sex tourism, the report claims, is prevalent in major cities such as Nairobi, Kisumu, Eldoret and coastal cities of Kenya.<ref name=dol10/>
Poverty and lack of schooling opportunities are major causes of child labour in Kenya. The country faces shortages of teachers and schools, overcrowding in schools, and procedural complications from children’s unregistered status. Kenyan law prevents access to schools to a child if he or she is unregistered as a citizen with Kenyan authorities. Currently, 44% of Kenyan children in rural areas remain unregistered. Thus, even when schools may be available, rural children are unable to prove citizenship, and these unregistered children risk losing the opportunity for schooling.
===Madagascar=== [[File:Working Child Brickaville Madagascar.jpg|thumb|upright|Child labour in Brickaville, a city in [[Atsinanana]] region of Madagascar.]] Children are common in small scale mines of [[Madagascar]]. Some children are involved in salt mining, quarry work, gem and gold ore collection. About 58% of children in these mines are younger than age 12. According to IPEC, Child labourers in these mines usually come from families who are in precarious economic situation.<ref name=iloafr/>
According to a United States-based 2010 report, about 22% of Madagascar children aged 5–14, or over 1.2 million work. Another French based group suggests Madagascar child labour exceeds 2.4 million, with over 540,000 children aged 5–9 working. About 87% of the child labour is in agriculture, mainly in the production of vanilla, tea, cotton, cocoa, copra (dried meat of coconut), sisal, shrimp harvest and fishing. Malagasy children engaged in domestic service work an average of 12 hours per day.<ref name=dol10>{{cite web|title=2010 Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor - U.S. Department of Labor|year=2011|url=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/programs/ocft/PDF/2010TDA.pdf|access-date=2012-07-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915195911/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/programs/ocft/PDF/2010TDA.pdf#|archive-date=2012-09-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Enquête nationale sur le travail des enfants à Madagascar, 2007|publisher=ILO|year=2008|url=http://www.ilo.org/ipecinfo/product/viewProduct.do?productId=9350}}</ref>
Several internationally funded efforts were involved in Madagascar to help reduce and prevent child labour. However these stopped, after the government change following 2009 coup, because much of the funding from international donors, including the African Union, European Union, World Bank and the United States, was suspended.
===Morocco=== A 2010 report estimates about 150,000 children aged between 5 and 14 were working in [[Morocco]]. Agriculture and domestic services are the predominant employers. Young girls, locally called as ''petites bonnes'' (little maids), are sent to work as live in domestic servants, many aged 10 or less. These ''petites bonnes'' come from very poor families, face conditions of involuntary servitude, including long hours without breaks, absence of holidays, physical, verbal and sexual abuse, withheld wages and even restrictions on their movement. They are denied education. More visible forms of child labour includes street children in Casablanca, Marrakech, Fès and Mèknes. These children survive by selling cigarettes, begging, shining shoes, washing cars and working as porters and packers in ports.<ref name=dol10/>
The Ministry of Planning in Morocco estimates that there are between 60,000 and 100,000 ''petites bonnes'' in the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=Child Labour in Morocco: The Socio-economic Background of the "Little Maids" Phenomenon|author=Mehdi Lahlou|publisher=Ministry of Planning, Morocco|url=http://www.araburban.org/childcity/Papers/English/Lahlou%20Morocco.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303123720/http://www.araburban.org/ChildCity/Papers/English/Lahlou%20Morocco.pdf|archivedate=2012-03-03|df=}}</ref> Studies commissioned by the Morocco government finds poverty and lack of school, often in combination, are primary causes of the little maids phenomenon in Morocco. Additionally, rural parents do not believe that an education or a diploma of any sort can help their girls find a job.
===Nigeria=== {{Main article|Child labour in Nigeria}} In 2006, there were about 15 million child labourers younger than age 14 in [[Nigeria]]. Many of these worked in hazardous conditions and for long hours. Poverty was the main driver of child labour, and the income of these children was a major part of their impoverished families income. Vast majority of child labour in Nigeria worked in agriculture and semi-formal or informal economy. Domestic servants were the least visible form of child labour, and often sexually harassed. Amongst informal economy and public places, street vending employed 64%. Midst informal enterprises in semipublic places, children were often observed as mechanics and bus conductors.<ref name=n2006>{{cite web|title=Child Labour - Nigeria, 2006|publisher=UNICEF|year=2007|url=http://www.unicef.org/wcaro/WCARO_Nigeria_Factsheets_ChildLabour.pdf}}</ref>
About 6 million of Nigeria's children do not go to school at all. In the current conditions, these children do not have the time, energy or resources to go to school.
===Rwanda=== ILO estimates [[Rwanda]] has 400,000 child workers. Of these, 120,000 are thought to be involved in the worst forms of child labour and 60,000 are child domestic workers.<ref name=iloafr/>
=== Swaziland === {{Main article|Child labour in Swaziland}}
===Tanzania=== {{main article|Child labour in Tanzania}}
===Zambia=== The government of [[Zambia]] estimates there are some 595,000 child workers in the country. Of these, 58% are aged 14 or less. Many are employed in informal mining operations.
The United States Department of Labor estimated, in its 2010 report, about 33% of Zambian children aged 5–14 work. Agriculture is the dominant employer, and with mining employs 98% of all child labour in Zambia. The informal sectors witnessing the worst form of child labour include cotton plantations, tobacco, fishing, tea, coffee and charcoal. Child labour is common in mining. However, this is witnessed in small artisanal and traditional mines, where the children extract emeralds, amethyst, aquamarines, tourmalines and garnets. Child labour is also present in mines of lead, zinc and copper ores. They do not wear any protective equipment to protect their eyes or face or body; injuries are common.<ref name=dol10/>
Child trafficking for purposes of hazardous labour is prevalent in Zambia. Children in agriculture and domestic service are exchanged for money, goods and gifts to family members. Zambia has strict laws against trafficking and child labour. However, implementation and enforcement of its laws has proven to be difficult.
According to ILO, child labour in Zambia is a coping strategy for the children and families when adult breadwinners die, fall ill, or when families are simply unable to make ends meet.<ref>{{cite web|title=The global crisis and rising child labour in Zambia’s mining communities: Are we facing a downward decent work spiral?|author=ILO Lusaka Office|year=2009|url=http://www.ilo.org/public/english/support/lib/financialcrisis/featurestories/story26.htm}}</ref>
==Dynamics== [[File:Child labour in Egypt.jpg|thumb|upright|Home-based carpet weaving enterprise in [[Egypt]] deploying child labour.]] International Labor Organization (ILO) stated that first of all, poverty is the greatest single force driving children into the workplace.<ref name=ilo2008a>{{cite web|title=Child labor - causes|year=2008|publisher=ILO, United Nations|url=http://www.ilo.org/public/english/region/eurpro/moscow/areas/ipec/causes.htm}}</ref> Another major factor driving children to harmful labor is the lack of schools and poor quality of schooling.<ref>{{cite web|title=CHILD LABOR: ISSUES, CAUSES AND INTERVENTIONS|author1=Faraaz Siddiqi |author2=Harry Anthony Patrinos |publisher=The World Bank|year=1999|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EDUCATION/Resources/278200-1099079877269/547664-1099079934475/547667-1135281552767/Child_Labor_issues.pdf}}</ref>
===Child labour laws in Africa=== [[File:Carte de ratification des conventions 138 et 182.png|thumb|Most African nations have ratified worldwide child labour-related conventions. African countries colored in green had national laws, as of 2006, equivalent to ILO Conventions 138 and 182. Additional countries, except South Sudan and Somalia, too have ratified ILO Conventions since then.]] Most African governments have formally adopted the three [[Child labour#Child labour laws and initiatives|International Labour Organization (ILO) Conventions]]. In addition, many have signed a memorandum of understanding with ILO to launch a programme under the International Programme for the Elimination of Child Labour (IPEC).
[[Nigeria]], for example, is now an active member of IPEC. It is also implementing the West Africa Cocoa Agriculture Project. Nigeria's Child Rights Act is now part of its Labour Act, and it prohibits exploitative labour from children. Some states, like [[Anambra State|Anambra]], have also banned children from working during school hours.<ref name=n2006/><ref>{{cite web|title=National programme on the elimination of child labour in Nigeria|year=2005|publisher=ILO|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_mas/---eval/documents/publication/wcms_149868.pdf}}</ref>
[[South Africa]] has made it a criminal offence to employ a child under the age of 15, except with a permit from the Department of Labour to employ children in the performing arts. Sections 43 through 47 of its Employment Act also makes it illegal to employ children aged 15 to 18 if the work is inappropriate for their age or something that places them at risk.<ref>{{cite web|title=Basic Guide to Child Labour|publisher=Department of Labour, Republic of South Africa|year=2012|url=https://www.labour.gov.za/legislation/acts/basic-guides/basic-guide-to-child-labour}}</ref>
[[Kenya]] passed a Children's Act in 2001. Section 10 of this Act protects children and youth below age 18 from economic exploitation and any work that is likely to be hazardous or to interfere with the child’s education, or to be harmful to the childspiritual, moral or social development. The law also forbids hiring anyone less than age of 18 for military or in any armed conflict.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Laws of Kenya - The Children Act 2001|year=2007|publisher=Kenya Police - National Council for Law Reporting|url=http://www.kenyapolice.go.ke/resources/Childrens_Act_No_8_of_2001.pdf}}</ref>
[[Ghana]], as another example, forbids child labour. Section 87 of its Children's Act 1998 forbids any person from employing a chiId in exploitative labour, or in any engagement that deprives the child of its health, education or development. Section 88 prohibits anyone from employing any child at night, that is between the hours of eight o'clock in the evening and six o'clock in the morning. The Act's section 89 to 90 allow children above the age of 13 to engage in light work, and those aged over 15 non-hazardous work.<ref>{{cite web|title=ACT OF THE PARLIAMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF GHANA ENTITLED THE CHILDREN'S ACT, 1998|publisher=Yale University|year=2002|url=http://www.law.yale.edu/rcw/rcw/jurisdictions/afw/ghana/ghana_childrens_act.pdf|access-date=2012-07-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917020312/http://www.law.yale.edu/rcw/rcw/jurisdictions/afw/ghana/Ghana_Childrens_Act.pdf#|archive-date=2012-09-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
While substantial legislation is now in place in almost all of Africa, legal enforcement remains a challenge.
===Non-governmental organizations=== ILO has a number of projects in Africa that seek to reduce, and ultimately eliminate child labour in Africa. One such project, launched in 2006 is focussed on west African nations of [[Benin]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Cape Verde]], [[Ivory Coast]], [[Gambia]], [[Ghana]], [[Guinea]], [[Guinea-Bissau]], [[Liberia]], [[Mali]], [[Niger]], [[Nigeria]], [[Senegal]], [[Sierra Leone]], and [[Togo]]. This project, started in 2009, aims at worst forms of child labour in west Africa. It has two main components: the first will support national efforts to eliminate the worst forms of child labour, while the second aims at mobilizing sub-regional policy makers and improving sub-regional cooperation for the elimination of the worst forms of child labour among all fifteen member States of the [[Economic Community of West African States]] (ECOWAS).<ref>{{cite web|title=Eliminating the Worst Forms of Child Labour in West Africa and Strengthening Sub-Regional Cooperation through ECOWAS–I|publisher=ILO, United Nations|year=2011|url=http://www.ilo.org/public/english/region/afpro/abuja/projects/nigecowas_1.htm}}</ref>
KURET project, which is an acronym for Combating Exploitive Child Labor Through Education in [[Kenya]], [[Uganda]], [[Rwanda]], and [[Ethiopia]] Together, is a regional effort to prevent exploitive child labor through education. Funded by the United States Department of Labor and implemented by World Vision, the Academy for Educational Development, and the International Rescue Committee, KURET began in September 2004. The regional office is located in Kampala, Uganda. A report in 2009 claims it made a difference in the lives of thousands of children in this region of Africa.<ref>{{cite web|title=Independent Final Evaluation of the Combating Exploitive Child Labor Through Education in Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, and Ethiopia Together (KURET) Project: Rwanda Country Report|author=Julian Ntezimana|year=2009|url=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/programs/ocft/tcp/KURET-report3.pdf|access-date=2012-07-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121209202550/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/programs/ocft/tcp/KURET-report3.pdf#|archive-date=2012-12-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Child labour in Botswana]] * [[Child labour in Lesotho]] * [[Child labour in Namibia]] * [[Child labour in Swaziland]] * [[Children in cocoa production]] * [[Child Labour Programme of Action (South Africa)]] * [[International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour]], IPEC * [[International Research on Working Children]]
'''South Asia:''' * [[Child labour in Bangladesh]] * [[Child labour in India]]
'''General:''' * [[Slavery in contemporary Africa]] * [[Child labour]] * [[Child slavery]] * [[Child soldiers]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120630033018/http://www.childinfo.org/labour_countrydata.php A UNICEF web resource with tables of % children who work for a living, by each African country and by gender] *[http://www.dol.gov/ilab/reports/child-labor/africa.htm Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor in Sub-Saharan Africa - U.S. Department of Labor] *[http://info.worldbank.org/etools/docs/library/250083/toolkitfr/pdf/andvig2.pdf Issues in child labor in Africa - A World Bank report] *[http://www.unicef.org/esaro/5480_child_labour_sexual_exploitation.html Child labour and commercial sexual exploitation - A UNICEF report] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/24/world/africa/24zambia.html?pagewanted=all Africa Adds to Miserable Ranks of Child Workers - A New York Times report] *[http://www.12to12.org/ An ILO sponsored website to help eliminate child labour] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/people/features/childrensrights/childrenofconflict/work.shtml A BBC World Service collage of articles on child labour in conflict-prone regions of the world, including Africa] *[http://www.dw.de/dw/article/0,,16015109,00.html Working hard from dawn to midnight - A Deutsche Welle (Germany) article on child labour in Africa] *[http://www.sweden.gov.se/content/1/c6/08/52/10/13ee04c3.pdf Demography and the development potential of sub-Saharan Africa - A report submitted to the Swedish parliament on child labour in Africa]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/01/child-labour-behind-smart-phone-and-electric-car-batteries Exposed: Child labour behind smart phone and electric car batteries]- [[Amnesty International|Amesty]] report, 19 January 2016

{{Infobox airline | airline=First Cambodia Airlines | image=FirstCambodiaAirlines.jpg | caption=First Cambodia Airlines logo | IATA=F6 | ICAO=FCC | callsign=First Cambodia | founded=February 2004 | commenced= | ceased=2 August 2004 | bases=[[Phnom Penh International Airport]] | fleet_size=See [[#Fleet|Fleet]] below | destinations=See [[#Services|Services]] below | headquarters=Cambodia }}
<!--[[File:Fkh.jpg|right]] commenting out image with no source/bad FairUse claim--> '''First Cambodia Airlines''' （SC：柬埔寨第一航空）was a privately owned [[airline]] based in [[Cambodia]]. Because of financial problems, it ceased operations in 2004.
==Code data==
*[[International Air Transport Association|IATA]] Code: '''F6''' *[[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]] Code: '''FCC''' *[[Airline call sign|Callsign]]: '''FIRST CAMBODIA'''
==History==
The airline was established in February 2004, but ceased operations on 2 August 2004 after financial difficulties meant its aircraft had to be returned to the lessor.
==Services==
First Cambodia Airlines operated services from [[Phnom Penh]] to [[Singapore]], [[Kuala Lumpur]] and [[Guangzhou]].
==Fleet==
The First Cambodia Airlines fleet consisted of 1 leased [[Airbus A320|Airbus A320-232]] aircraft from ILFC.
==External links== {{commons category|First Cambodia Airlines}} *[http://www.planespotters.net/Airline/First_Cambodia_Airlines?show=all First Cambodia Airlines Former Fleet Detail]
{{Airlines of Cambodia}}
[[Category:Defunct airlines of Cambodia]] [[Category:Airlines established in 2004]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2004]]

Red and white are the city's colours.
This flag remembers the coat of arms of the old Piast Duchy of Głogów and [[Jawor County|Jawor]].

{{Infobox noble house |surname = Goubau |type = noble family |native_name = |native_name_lang = |other_name = |coat of arms = File:Praenobilis Familia GOVBAV.jpg |image_size = 225px |alt = |caption = |country = [[Image:Bandera cruz de Borgoña 2.svg|22px]] [[Spanish Netherlands]] :[[Image:Austrian Low Countries Flag.svg|22px]] [[Austrian Netherlands]] |estates = Cortewalle Castle |parent house = |titles = Lord of Mespelaere
Lord of Triest
Lord of Saint-Fontaine
Lord of Ghysegem |founded = |founder = |current head = |dissolution = |ethnicity = |cadet branches = Goubau d'Hovorst |notes = }} [[File:Schloss Cortewalle02.jpg|thumb|Cortewalle Castle, Beveren.]] [[File:Justus van Egmont - Alexander, Jan-Cornelis and Maria-Aldegonda Goubau.jpg|thumb|Alexander IV Goubau, and John V Cornelis Goubau as Children, painted by [[Justus van Egmont]] in 1663.]] [[File:Peter Paul Rubens - Virgin and Child - WGA20182.jpg|thumb|[[Alexander I Goubau]] and his wife, [[Virgin and Child (Rubens)|painted by Rubens]]]] '''The Goubau family''' was an important noble family of [[Antwerp]], many of its members are related to other important families. In 1633 king [[Felipe IV of Spain]] granted nobility. In 1866 the last member of the family died. The family had many important residences amongst them ''den Wolsack'' (1593) in Antwerpen and [[Cortewalle Castle]] in [[Beveren]]. In Mespelare and Dendermonde they did important gift to the local church and founded the so-called ''Spaans hof'' in 1643 to Honour [[Saint-Aldegonde|Aldegondis van Maubeuge]]. In Mortsel they resided in Ten Dorpe Castle{{cite web|url=https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/13654 |title=Kasteel Ten Dorpe - Erfgoedobjecten - Inventaris Onroerend Erfgoed |website=Inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}} ==Members== # '''Henri Goubau''', knight of Calatrava.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=toFFAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA271&dq=Goubau%20noblesse&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFp6-BqprSAhUHDsAKHamWDfoQ6AEIKTAC#v=onepage&q=Goubau%20noblesse&f=false|title=Recueil historique, généalogique, chronologique et nobiliaire des maisons et familles illustres et nobles du royaume, précédé de la généalogie historique de la maison royale des Pays-Bas Nassau-Orange|first=C. de|last=Francquen|date=1 January 1826|publisher=Demanet|via=Google Books}} ## '''[[Joannes I Goubau, Lord of Saint-Fontaine]]''', (1503-1581):{{cite web|url=http://balat.kikirpa.be/photo.php?path=A045407&objnr=50007204&nr=2 |title=Balat Kik-Irpa |website=Balat.kikirpa.be |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}} marr. Joanne Cossiers{{cite web|url=http://balat.kikirpa.be/photo.php?path=A045408&objnr=50007205&nr=3 |title=Balat Kik-Irpa |website=Balat.kikirpa.be |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}} in 1534, daughter of Joannes Cossiers or Cosserie and [[Schetz|Barbe Schetz]]. ### [[Joannes II Goubau]], marr. Joanna Stayaerts. ### Henricus Goubau ### Jacobus Goubau, marr. Catharine Maynaert. ### Joanna Goubau, died 1575. ### Gaspar Goubau ### Antonius Goubau ### '''[[Alexander I Goubau]]''', (1540-1614): Grand Aumonier of Antwerpen, buried in the cathedral. #### Anna Goubau, (1568-) #### [[Alexander II Goubau]] (1571-) #### Maria Goubau, (1573-) #### '''[[Joannes III Goubau, Lord of Ghysegem]]''', (1575-1645): Grand Aumonier of Antwerpen, Knighted in 1633. Marr. Magd. Vecquemans. ##### '''[[Alexander III Goubau, Lord of Ghysegem]]''', (1598-1668), knighted 1648, [[List of mayors of Antwerp|Mayor of Antwerpen]], Grand Aumonier of Antwerpen, 1629. marr. Anna Doncker. ###### '''[[Joannes IV Goubau, Lord of Ghysegem]]''', (1630-) : knighted 1655, marr Marie Cornelie crook. ####### '''[[Alexander IV Goubau, Lord of Mespelaere]]''', (1658-1712): Grand Aumonier of Antwerpen, Marr. in 1690 [[Peter Paul Rubens|Maria Catharina Rubens]], granddaughter of [[Nicolaas Rubens, Lord of Rameyen]]. ######## [[Georges Alexander Goubau, Lord of Mespelaere]] (1697-1760) : marr. Maria Bosschaert. ####### [[Joannes V Cornelis Goubau]], (1660-1702), Grand Aumonier of Antwerpen in 1689: marr. Susanne van Colen. ##### '''[[François Goubau, Lord of Triest]]''', (1611-1647) : marr. Isabella vanden Broecke. ###### [[Joannes VI Frans Goubau, Lord of Triest]], (1646-1683), Lord of Beveren, knighted on 10 April 1679 by Charles II: Marr. Margaretha-Catharina Gerardi. ####### [[Peter Frans Goubau]], (1680-1749): marr. Maria Lucretia Bernaerts. ######## [[Charles Henri Goubau]], (1708-1776): councillor of the [[Great Council of Mechelen]], marr. Regina de Villegas (1722-1794 . ######### [[Melchior Goubau|Melchior Joseph François Ghislain Goubau]], (1757-1836): councillor of the [[Great Council of Mechelen]], marr. Marie-Jeanne de Villegas de Pellenberg. ######### [[Emmanuel Goubau]], (1760-1828), marr. [[Maria Isabella de Brouchoven de Bergeyck]] (1773-1819). ######### [[Eugène Joseph Goubau]], (1761-1831): Lord maoyor of the [[Brugse Vrije]]. == Family tree == {{family tree/start |summary=The Goubau family tree.}} {{family tree | | | | | | | | | HEN | | | | | | HEN=Henri Goubau}} {{family tree | | | | | | | | | |!| | | | | | |}} {{family tree | | | | | | | | | JOI |y| JOA | | JOI='''[[Joannes I Goubau]]'''

revision.text:
The '''Heers Formation''' ({{lang-nl|Formatie van Heers}}; {{lang-fr|Formation de Heers}}; abbreviation: Hs) is a [[formation (stratigraphy)|geologic formation]] in the [[Subsurface (geology)|subsurface]] of [[Belgium]]. The formation consists of [[sand]] and [[marl]] and was deposited in the shallow sea that covered Belgium during the middle to late [[Selandian]] [[age (geology)|age]] of the [[Paleocene]] [[Epoch (geology)|epoch]].
The formation is subdivided into two [[member (stratigraphy)|members]]: at the base green, [[glauconite|glauconiferous]] sand ([[Orp Member]]), on top calcareous [[clay]] and marl in which plant [[fossil]]s have been found ([[Gelinden Member]]). This sequence formed during a [[marine transgression]]. The Orp Member represents a near coastal marine environment, the Gelinden Member formed in shallow marine circumstances but further from the land.
The Heers Formation occurs in the subsurface of the northern and eastern parts of [[Flanders]]. In [[Limburg (Belgium)|Limburg]] it reaches its maximal thickness at about 60 meters. The Heers Formation is stratigraphically on top of [[Cretaceous]] and early Paleocene deposits, such as the [[Opglabbeek Formation]] or the [[Houthem Formation]]. The Heers Formation is almost everywhere overlain by the [[Hannut Formation]] (clay, sand and [[limestone]] from the late Paleocene).
The Orp and Gelinden members are also recognized in the [[Netherlands]] (north of Belgium). Dutch stratigraphers see them as part of the [[Landen Formation]].
==References== {{Reflist}} *Laga, P. & De Geyter, G.; 1988: ''Formatie van Heers'', in: Maréchal, R. & Laga, P.: ''Voorstel lithostratigrafische indeling van het Paleogeen'', [[Belgische Geologische Dienst]], [[City of Brussels|Brussels]], p. 52-58. ({{nl}}) *Laga, P.; Louwye, S. & Geets, S. (eds.); 2001: ''Paleogene and Neogene lithostratigraphic units (Belgium)'', Geologica Belgica 4(1-2), p. 135-152.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Heers}} [[Category:Lithostratigraphy of Belgium]] [[Category:Paleocene]] [[Category:Paleogene Europe]]
{{Europe-geologic-formation-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=September 2007}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 14 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = Communications | operator = [[Intelsat]] | COSPAR_ID = 2009-064A | SATCAT = 36097 | mission_duration = 16 years | spacecraft_bus = [[LS-1300]] | manufacturer = [[Space Systems/Loral]] | dry_mass = {{convert|2517|kg}} | launch_mass = {{convert|5663|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|23 November 2009, 06:55:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Atlas V]] 431 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41|SLC-41]] | launch_contractor = [[United Launch Alliance]] | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = 19 April 2017[https://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=36097 INTELSAT 14]. N2YO.com. Retrieved 19 April 2017. | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35,783.5|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35,805.5|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 0° | orbit_period = 1,436.1 minutes | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42,165.0|km|mi}} | orbit_longitude = 45° west | orbit_slot = | apsis = gee | trans_band = 40 C-band
22 Ku-band | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = 72 MHz (8 C-band)
36 MHz (others) | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[Americas]], [[Europe]], [[Africa]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 10-02]] (Intelsat 10) | next_mission = [[Intelsat 15]] }} '''Intelsat 14''' is a [[communications satellite]] owned by [[Intelsat]] located at 45° West [[longitude]], serving the [[Americas]], [[Europe]], and [[Africa]]n markets. Intelsat 14 replaced [[Intelsat 1R]] which was at the end of its design life. It was built by [[Space Systems Loral]], as part of its [[LS-1300]] line. ==Communications payload== Intelsat 14 has a C-band and Ku band payload, each of which is further divided to provide service to 2 each coverage areas.http://www.intelsat.com/flash/coverage-maps/index.html The C-band payload has an Americas beam which covers the southern part of the [[United States]], all of [[Mexico]], [[Central America]], and all of [[South America]]. A second C-band beam provides coverage for Western Europe and Africa. The Ku band payload also has an Americas beam which covers the Alabama, Georgia and Florida, all of the [[Caribbean]], Central America and all of South America except [[Brazil]]. The Ku band US/Europe/Africa beam covers the southern eastern United States, Western Europe, and the northern western African countries. Intelsat 14 also carries an experimental [[Radiation hardening|radiation-tolerant]] [[Internet Protocol|IP]] [[Router (computing)|router]] payload that can be connected to several of the C and Ku band channels. This experimental payload is known as [[IRIS (Internet Routing in Space)]] demonstration.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/6551807.stm | work=BBC News | title=Net reaches out to final frontier | date=April 13, 2007 | accessdate=May 5, 2010}} {| class="wikitable" ! Payload ! C band ! Ku Band |- ! Transponders | 40 | 22 |- ! Bandwidth | 32 at 36 MHz
8 at 72 MHz | 22 at 36 MHz |- ! Amplifier type | [[TWTA]] | [[TWTA]] |- ! Amplifier output | 50 watts | 120 watts |- ! Amplifier Redundancy | 2 groups of 16 for 12
2 groups of 10 for 8 | 2 groups of 14 for 11 |- ! Receiver redundancy | 4 for 2 | 4 for 2 |- ! Coverage | Americas, Europe, Africa | Americas, Europe, Africa |- ! Beacon frequency
Horizontal polarisation |3704.0 MHz |11694.0 MHz |- ! Beacon frequency
Vertical polarisation |3705.0 MHz |11695.0 MHz |- |} ==Launch== Intelsat 14 was launched from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 41]] November 23, 2009 on an [[Atlas V]] rocket flying in the 431 configuration. The satellite was released into a [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]] 1 hour and 58 minutes after lift-off.{{cite web |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/atlas/av024/status.html |title=Atlas Mission Status Center |author=Justin Ray |publisher=Spaceflight Now}}{{cite news|last= Graham|first= William|title=Intelsat 14 launches on Atlas V AV-024 at second attempt|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2009/11/live-intelsat-14-set-to-launch-on-atlas-v-av-024/|accessdate=November 22, 2009}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 2009}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2009]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] [[Category:Satellite television]]

'''''La règle de non-cumul''''' is a principle of [[French law]] which regulates whether an action should be brought under [[contract law]] (''la responsibilité civile'') or [[tort law]] (''la responsibilité delictuelle'').
It states that where there is a contract, an action can only be brought under contract law and when there is no contract an action can only be brought under tort law.
==References== * Droit Civil, Brigitte Hess-Fallon - (2005) 8eme edition.
{{DEFAULTSORT:La regle de non-cumul}} [[Category:French business law]]
{{Europe-law-stub}}

revision.text:
{{short description|A deep sea plateau from south west of New Caledonia to the Challenger Plateau, west of New Zealand}} [[Image:Zealandia topography.jpg|thumb|upright|The Lord Howe Rise is part of the continent known as [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]].]]
The '''Lord Howe Rise''' is a [[deep sea]] [[plateau]] which extends from south west of [[New Caledonia]] to the [[Challenger Plateau]], west of [[New Zealand]] in the south west of the [[Pacific Ocean]]. To its west is the [[Tasman Basin]] and to the east is the [[New Caledonia Basin]].<ref name="ga"/> Lord Howe Rise has a total area of about 1,500,000 square km,<ref name="ga">{{cite web |title=Lord Howe Rise |work=Regional petroleum geology of Australia |publisher=[[Geoscience Australia]] |date=16 June 2003 |url=http://www.ga.gov.au/oceans/ea_LHoweRis.jsp |accessdate=2007-04-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313111159/http://www.ga.gov.au/oceans/ea_LHoweRis.jsp |archivedate=13 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> and generally lies about 750 to 1,200 metres under water.<ref name="hbdpsp">{{cite book |title=Seafloor Geomorphology As Benthic Habitat: GeoHAB Atlas of Seafloor Geomorphic Features and Benthic Habitats |last=Harris |first=Peter T. |author2=Scott L. Nichol |author3=Tara J. Anderson |author4=Andrew D. Heap |chapter=57: Habitats and Benthos of a Deep Sea Marginal Plateau, Australia |year=2011 |publisher=Elsevier |isbn=0123851408 |page=777 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oSiDGetPxpgC |accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref> It is part of [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]], a much larger [[continent]] that is now mostly submerged, and so is composed of [[continental crust]].
==Formation== The Lord Howe Rise was formed by [[seafloor spreading]] which also resulted in the creation of the Tasman Sea.<ref name="vtpi">{{cite book |title=Vegetation of the Tropical Pacific Islands |last=Mueller-Dombois |first=Dieter |year=1998 |publisher=Springer |isbn=0387983139 |page=167 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7UB5d33i8WkC |accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref> It was [[rift]]ed away from [[Eastern Australia]] by a [[mid-ocean ridge]] that was active from 80 to 60 million years ago, and now lies 800 kilometres offshore from mainland [[Australia]].
The Lord Howe Rise contains a line of [[seamount]]s called the [[Lord Howe Seamount Chain]] which formed during the [[Miocene]] period when this part of Zealandia existed over the [[Lord Howe hotspot]]. Lord Howe was the last volcano to erupt on the rise.<ref name="vtpi"/>
==Islands, reefs and seamounts== [[Lord Howe Island]] and [[Ball's Pyramid]] cap a seamount towards the central east of the rise in an area known as the Lord Howe platform. The Lord Howe Seamount Chain extends northwards along the rise. The seamounts provide habitat to a diverse range of marine species which attracts commercial fishers, but cover a very small area, less than 1% of the total area of Lord Howe Rise.<ref>Harris, P.T., 2011. Benthic environments of the Lord Howe Rise submarine plateau: Introduction to the special volume. Deep-Sea Research Part II 58, 883–888</ref>
Further north is the [[Elizabeth Reef|Elizabeth]] and [[Middleton Reef|Middleton]] part of the [[Coral Sea Islands]], which together with reefs around [[Lord Howe Island]] are the most southern coral reefs on Earth.<ref>Woodroffe, C.D., Dickson, M.E., Brooke, B.P., Kennedy, D.M., 2005. Episodes of reef growth at [[Lord Howe Island]], the southernmost reef in the southwest Pacific. Global and Planetary Change 49, 222–237</ref>
==Environment== The [[Seabed]] on the rise is mostly sandy mud with some volcanic outcrops, gravel and boulders.<ref name="hbdpsp"/>
The ''[[Coris bulbifrons]]'' is endemic to reefs only on the Lord Howe Rise and the [[West Norfolk Rise]].<ref name="omb">{{cite book |title=Oceanography and Marine Biology, Volume 49 |last=Gibson |first=Robin N. |authorlink= |author2=R. J. A. Atkinson |author3=J. D. M. Gordon |year=2011 |publisher=CRC Press |isbn=1439853649 |page=216 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7h-Jw8bbmdgC |accessdate=26 June 2013}}</ref>
===Resources=== Much of the basin remains unexplored in relation to oil and gas reserves.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2008/04/21/1208742853789.html |title=National bonanza sitting on shelf |author=Misha Schubert and Barry Fitzgerald |accessdate=2009-12-04 |date=2009-04-22 |work=[[The Age]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Digital]] }}</ref>
==See also== * {{annotated link|Chatham Rise}} * {{annotated link|Norfolk Ridge}} * {{annotated link|South Tasman Rise}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{coord|28|S|161|E|display=title}}
[[Category:Plateaus of Oceania]] [[Category:Underwater ridges of the Pacific Ocean]] [[Category:Zealandia]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox royalty | type = monarch | name = Pan Htwar | image = Queen Pan Htwar.jpg | caption = Queen Pan Htwar statue | reign = c. 180 BCE–610 CE | coronation = | succession = [[List of Burmese monarchs|Queen regnant of Beikthano]] | predecessor = ''new office'' | successor = Duttabaung | suc-type = Successor | reign1 = | succession1 = [[List of Burmese consorts|Queen consort of Sri Ksetra]] | predecessor1 = herself | successor1 = | suc-type1 = Successor | spouse = Duttabaung | house = Beikthano | father = Sula Thamawa | mother = Sanda Muhki | religion = [[Theravada Buddhism]] }} '''Pan Htwar''' ({{lang-my|ပန်ထွာ}}) also known as ''' Princess Thonbanhla''' was the Queen of [[Beikthano]], the ancient cities of the [[Pyu city-states|Pyu Kingdom]]. She was a strong spiritual lady of war and fame.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://myanmarlive.net/ဗိႆႏိုးဘုရင္မ-ပန္ထြာဧကရ/|title= ဗိဿနိုးဘုရင်မ ပန်ထွာဧကရီ ဆိုတဲ့ အမျိုးသမီးပဒေသရာဇ် ခေါင်းဆောင်အကြောင်း|publisher=Myanmar Live|date=17 January 2018|accessdate=28 July 2018|language=my}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thutazone.net/2018/01/13/ပန္ထြာဘုရင္မ-ရဲ႕-ဗိႆႏိုး/|title=ပန်ထွာဘုရင်မရဲ့ ဗိဿနိုးမြို့ဟောင်းအကြောင်း|publisher=Thuta Zone|date=13 January 2018|accessdate=28 July 2018|language=my}}</ref>
==Legend== Pan Htwar was the only daughter of Sula Thamawa, a son of Maha Thado Yarzar (King Naga Naing), the legendary King of [[Tagaung Kingdom]]. Her mother Sanda Muhki was the [[Ogress]]-[[Nymph|nymph]] from [[Lanka|Lanka Dipa]].
Her history records the wars period between [[Sri Ksetra]] and [[Beikthano]] and of the fighting that took place. The Lord of Celestial Beings [[Thagyamin|Sakra]] gave a big magical drum named "Atula Sidaw" to the Queen. The queen was able to repel all her ememy forces with the help of this magical drum. Whatever enemies approached [[Beikthano]], according to the legend the city was created for Pan Htwar by the Hindu god [[Vishnu]]. The queen was assumed as the little sister of god Vishnu in previous life. [[Sri Ksetra]] King Duttabaung had to resort to a stratagem to take away the magical powers of the drum before he could capture the city and sent imitate monk to Beikthano, her drum was destroyed and her empire and kingdom was flamed. Her hatred upon the King and the imitate monks, still flows in the veins of [[Beikthano]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.gomyanmartours.com/beikthano/|title=Beikthano|publisher=Go Myanmar Tours|date=|accessdate=28 July 2018|language=}}</ref>
King Duttabaung was the son of Maha Thamawa, twin brother of Sula Thamawa. So, Queen Pan Htwar is the half-sister of Duttabaung, and she married to the king for revenge.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mmtimes.com/lifestyle/21575-an-ancient-princess-still-haunts-pyay.html|title=An ancient princess still haunts Pyay|publisher=[[The Myanmar Times]]|date=26 July 2016|accessdate=28 July 2018|author=Khin Wyne Phyu Phyu}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.yoyarlay.com/knowledge/tourism/744-2017-03-03-03-28-29|title=အချစ်ကြီးလှတဲ့ ဒွတ္တပေါင်ဘုရင် နဲ့ အငြိုးကြီးလှတဲ့ ပန်ထွာဘုရင်မ တို့ရဲ့ ပုံရိပ်များ ထင်ကျန်ခဲ့ရာ သရေခေတ္တရာမြို့ဟောင်း|publisher=Yoyarlay|date=3 March 2017|accessdate=26 July 2018|author=Chan Myae Ei|language=my}}</ref> She became Queen consort of King Duttabaung. The king’s other consorts were jealous of her beauty, and conspired against her. They told Duttabaung that her loveliness was a magic trick, and that in fact she resembled a horrible ogre. She was assassinated by poison.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://myanmar24h.com/news-8-16-d21d984882a65b719c6693339dc88f74|title=မကျွတ်လွတ်သေးတဲ့ ဗိဿနိုး ပန်ထွာဘုရင်မ|publisher=Myanmar 24H|date=|accessdate=28 July 2018|language=my}}</ref>
==Spiritual life== [[File:Pan Htwar statue.jpg|50|thumb|Statue of goddess Pan Htwar]] After her death, she became a [[Nat (spirit)|Nat]] (spirit) and ''Goddess of Mahar Myaing deep forest''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mmbookdownload.com/book_reader.html?file=35990|title=Mahar Myaing Deep Forest Sasanar Pyu Trip and Dhamma Light of Queen Pan Htwar|publisher=Myanmar Book|date=|accessdate=29 July 2018|author=Mg Thwae Chun}}</ref> She was also known as the ''Goddess of [[Beikthano]]'' or '''Beikthano Nat'''. Some people believe that if her spirit is accorded the proper worship and respect, good health and bountiful harvests will follow.
[[File:Queen Pan Htwar statue.jpg|150px|thumb|Pan Htwar statue in the shrine]] During the Buddhist Lent, villagers from Mhaw Zar and Mu Htaw villages collect donations to fund a ceremony of worship for Thonbanhla, held on the eve of the full moon day of [[Waso]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1lKmlyo3QX8 History of Queen Pan Htwar]
{{authority control}} {{Burmese nats}}
[[Category:Burmese nats]] [[Category:City-states]] [[Category:Queens regnant]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox criminal | name = Patrick Henry | image_size = | image_name = | image_caption = | birth_date = 31 March 1953 | birth_place = [[Troyes]], [[French Fourth Republic|France]] | cause = [[Lung cancer]] | death_date = 3 December 2017 (aged 64) | death_place = [[Lille]], France | alias = | occupation = [[Door-to-door|Travelling salesman]]
[[Printer (publishing)|Printer and publisher]] | charge = [[Child abduction]] and [[child murder]] (1977)
[[Drug trafficking]] (in possession of 10kg of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]]) (2003) | conviction_penalty = [[Life imprisonment]] (January 20, 1977)
Returned to his life prisoner condition, 4 year-term, €20,000 fine and the confiscation of money he had with him (around €8,000) (July 22, 2003) }} '''Patrick Henry''' (31 March 1953 – 3 December 2017) was a French criminal, [[cause célèbre]] and the subject of public and judicial controversy. He was convicted of the [[kidnap]]ping and [[murder]] of 8-year-old Philippe Bertrand in January 1976.{{cite news|url=http://www.liberation.fr/20-ans-de-faits-divers-a-libe/0101570168-le-cas-patrick-henry|title=Le cas Patrick Henry|language=French|publisher=[[Libération]]|author=Sorj Chalandon|date=29 May 2009|access-date=20 March 2012}} The trial began on 18 January 1977 and he was defended by Robert Bocquillon and [[Robert Badinter]]. A contentious issue in the trial was the validity of [[capital punishment in France]]; Badinter, a fervent supporter of its abolition, would ultimately convince the jury not to execute his client.Max Berley [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/09/news/france-debates-parole-after-24-years-of-prison-for-killer-of-a-child.html "France Debates Parole, After 24 Years of Prison, for Killer of a Child"], ''New York Times''; accessed 3 December 2017. This case is said to have had an influence in leading to the abolition of the death penalty in France in 1981. Henry was instead sentenced to [[Life imprisonment in France|life imprisonment]] and was [[parole]]d in 2001; however, he returned to jail two years later after having been caught trying to smuggle drugs into France. ==Death== Henry died of lung cancer in [[Lille]], aged 64, on 3 December 2017.[http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2017/12/03/97001-20171203FILWWW00114-mort-de-patrick-henry-detenu-pendant-40-ans-pour-le-meurtre-d-un-enfant.php L'ex-détenu Patrick Henry est mort]; accessed 3 December 2017. {{fr icon}} ==See also== ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Henry, Patrick (French murderer)}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:French murderers of children]] [[Category:20th-century French criminals]] [[Category:Deaths from lung cancer]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in France]] {{France-hist-stub}} {{Europe-law-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox civilian attack |title= Podujevo massacre |image= |caption= |location= [[Podujevo]], [[Kosovo]], [[FR Yugoslavia]] |target= Kosovo [[Albanians]] |date= 28 March 1999 |time= |timezone= [[Central European Time]] |type= Massacre |fatalities= 14 civilians, including women, children and the elderly<ref>{{cite web|publisher=B92|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/crimes.php?yyyy=2008&mm=12&dd=23&nav_id=55926|title=Podujevo massacre survivor testifies|date=December 23, 2008|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref> |injuries=5 |perps= [[Special Anti-Terrorist Unit (Serbia)|Special Anti-Terrorism Unit]], [[Scorpions (paramilitary)|Scorpions]] |motive= }}
The '''Podujevo massacre''' ({{lang-sq|Masakra e Podujevës}}, {{lang-sr|Masakr u Podujevu|script=Latn}}) is the name generally used to refer to the killing of 14 [[Kosovo Albanian]] civilians, mostly women and children, committed in March 1999 by the [[Scorpions (Serbia)|Scorpions]], a Serbian paramilitary organisation in conjunction with the [[Special Anti-Terrorist Unit (Serbia)|Special Anti-Terrorist Unit]] of Serbia, during the [[Kosovo War]]. One of the survivors of this massacre, Saranda Bogujevci, 13 years old when it occurred, received mass media attention after she successfully managed to bring to justice her case with the help of several [[NGO|organizations]] from [[Serbia]], [[Canada]] and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="crime">''[http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/balkans/crimesandcourage.html "Massacre at Podujevo, Kosovo"]'', CBC News Indepth, March 29, 2004.</ref>
==Aftermath== Goran Stoparić, at the time of the events serving in the Anti-Terrorism Unit (SAJ), gave evidence to bring the culprits to justice. In an interview to [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]], he speculated over the motives behind the actions committed by the irregular forces:
:"In my opinion, [their] only motive was the fact that the victims were Albanians, and perhaps because of some hidden immaturity or sickness of mind on their part. They would probably have killed them had they been Bosnians or Croats. But it is certain that they were killed because they were not Serbs."<ref name="crime" />
Serbian police arrested two members of a paramilitary unit called the [[Scorpions (paramilitary)|Scorpions]], Saša Cvjetan and Dejan Demirović, who freely gave incriminating statements and signed them. Demirović had moved to Canada and applied for [[political asylum]] but was deported back to his home country after a campaign orchestrated by human rights organizations.<ref name="crime" />
Demirović and Cvjetan were the only two people charged with the killings. Cvetjan was sentenced in Serbia to 20 years in prison.<ref>"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3520370.stm Serb jailed for Kosovo killings] ", BBC News, March 17, 2004.</ref>
On 10 April 2007, four members of the Scorpions paramilitary group were convicted and sentenced to lengthy prison sentences by Belgrade's War Crimes Court.<ref>[http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article2439541.ece Serb 'Scorpions' guilty of Srebrenica massacre] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930210556/http://news.independent.co.uk/europe/article2439541.ece |date=2007-09-30 }} - ''The Independent'', April 10, 2007</ref>
== See also == * [[List of massacres in Yugoslavia]] * [[List of massacres in the Kosovo War]] * [[War crimes in Kosovo]] * [[Battle of Podujevo]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.foxnews.com/wires/2008Dec11/0,4670,EUSerbiaWarCrimes,00.html Massacre described at Kosovo war crimes trial], [[Associated Press]]/[[Fox News Channel]], December 11, 2008
{{coord missing|Kosovo}}
[[Category:Podujevo]] [[Category:Serbian war crimes in the Kosovo War]] [[Category:Massacres in the Kosovo War]] [[Category:1999 crimes in Kosovo]] [[Category:Mass murder in 1999]] [[Category:Anti-Albanian sentiment]]
