{{Infobox scientist | name = Richard Alley | birth_name = Richard Blane Alley | image = Professor Richard Alley ForMemRS.jpg | image_size = | caption = Richard Alley in 2014, portrait via the [[Royal Society]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1957|8|18}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[State College, Pennsylvania]] | citizenship = | nationality = | ethnicity = | fields = | workplaces = [[Pennsylvania State University]] | alma_mater = {{Plainlist| * [[Ohio State University]] * [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] (PhD)}} | thesis_title = Transformations in polar firn | thesis_url = http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/16148211 | thesis_date = 1987 | doctoral_advisor = [[Charles R. Bentley]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = {{Plainlist| * [[Abrupt climate change]]{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/34346| year = 1998| title = Timing of abrupt climate change at the end of the Younger Dryas interval from thermally fractionated gases in polar ice| last1 = Severinghaus | first1 = J. P. | journal = Nature| volume = 391| issue = 6663| pages = 141| last2 = Sowers | first2 = T. | last3 = Brook | first3 = E. J. | last4 = Alley | first4 = R. B. | last5 = Bender | first5 = M. L. | bibcode = 1998Natur.391..141S}} * [[Glaciology]] * [[Ice sheet]]s{{cite web|title=NASA People|url=http://www.nasa.gov/vision/earth/environment/sealevel_alley_bio.html|publisher=''[[NASA]]''|accessdate=2008-10-01}}}} | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Fellow of the Royal Society|ForMemRS]] 2014 [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]]
[[Heinz Award]] with special focus on the Environment (2011)
[[American Geophysical Union|AGU]] Fellow (2000)https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1029/00EO00055 | religion = | signature = | footnotes = | website = {{URL|http://www.geosc.psu.edu/academic-faculty/alley-richard}} }} '''Richard Blane Alley''' (born 18 August 1957)Alexander E. Gates: Earth Scientists from A to Z, Facts on File, 2003 is an [[United States|American]] [[geologist]] and Evan Pugh [[Professor]] of [[Geosciences]] at [[Pennsylvania State University]]. He has authored more than 240 refereed scientific publications about the relationships between Earth's [[cryosphere]] and [[global climate change]],{{cite web|title=Citation for Richard Alley|url=http://www.geosc.psu.edu/documents/alley_seligman.pdf|publisher=''[[Penn State College of Earth and Mineral Sciences]]''|accessdate=2008-09-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517035013/http://www.geosc.psu.edu/documents/alley_seligman.pdf|archivedate=2008-05-17|df=}} and is recognized by the [[Institute for Scientific Information]] as a "highly cited researcher."{{cite web |title=Alley, Richard B. |url=http://hcr3.isiknowledge.com/author.cgi?&link1=Search&link2=Search%20Results&AuthLastName=alley&AuthFirstName=richard&AuthMiddleName=&AuthMailnstName=&CountryID=-1&DisciplineID=0&id=2481 |publisher=''[[Institute for Scientific Information]]'' |accessdate=2008-09-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070519223724/http://hcr3.isiknowledge.com/author.cgi |archivedate=19 May 2007 |df= }}[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=richard+alley Richard Alley publications], in [[Google Scholar]]{{Cite journal| last5=Taylor | first1=R. B.| last2=Mayewski | author1-link=Richard B. Alley| last6=Clark | first2=P. A.| last4=Stuiver| last3=Sowers| first3=T.| last1=Alley| first4=M.| first5=K. C.| first6=P. U. | title = Holocene climatic instability: A prominent, widespread event 8200 yr ago |journal=[[Geology (journal)|Geology]] |volume = 25| issue = 6 | pages = 483 | year = 1997 | doi = 10.1130/0091-7613(1997)025<0483:HCIAPW>2.3.CO;2|bibcode = 1997Geo....25..483A }}{{cite journal |title = Abrupt Climate Change |url = http://www.ecobb.dancingflames.org/dancingflames/EnvSci/Articles/EnvScipdffiles/Climate%20Models/AbruptClimateChange.pdf |first11 = J. M. |format = PDF |accessdate = |last11 = Wallace |journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume = 299 |issue = 5615 |pages = 2005–2010 |first10 = L. D. |date = Mar 2003 |doi = 10.1126/science.1081056 |pmid = 12663908 |bibcode = 2003Sci...299.2005A |last1 = Alley |first1 = R. B. |last2 = Marotzke |last10 = Talley |first2 = J. |last3 = Nordhaus |first3 = W. D. |last4 = Overpeck |first4 = J. T. |last5 = Peteet |first5 = D. M. |last6 = Pielke Jr |first6 = R. A. |last7 = Pierrehumbert |first7 = R. T. |last8 = Rhines |first8 = P. B. |last9 = Stocker |first9 = T. F. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170312182619/http://www.ecobb.dancingflames.org/dancingflames/EnvSci/Articles/EnvScipdffiles/Climate%20Models/AbruptClimateChange.pdf |archivedate = 2017-03-12 |df = }} ==Education== Alley was educated at [[Ohio State University]] and [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], where he was awarded a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in 1987.[http://www.geosc.psu.edu/academic-faculty/alley-richard Richard Alley] ==Research and Career== In 1999, Alley was invited to testify about [[climate change]] by Vice President [[Al Gore]],{{cite web|title=Guest Speakers|url=http://academic.ursinus.edu/ftn/speakers.htm|publisher=''[[Ursinus College]]''|accessdate=2008-09-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120726090650/http://academic.ursinus.edu/ftn/speakers.htm|archivedate=2012-07-26|df=}} in 2003 by the U.S. Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, and before the U.S. House Committee on Science and Technology in 2007{{cite web|title=Changes in Ice: The 2007 IPCC Assessment|url=http://democrats.science.house.gov/Media/File/Commdocs/hearings/2007/full/08feb/alley_testimony.pdf|publisher=''[[United States House of Representatives]]''|accessdate=2008-09-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924230501/http://democrats.science.house.gov/Media/File/Commdocs/hearings/2007/full/08feb/alley_testimony.pdf|archivedate=2008-09-24|df=}} and again in 2010.{{cite web|title=The Role of Warming in Melting Ice and Sea-Level Rise, and the Possibility of Abrupt Climate Changes|url=http://democrats.science.house.gov/Media/file/Commdocs/hearings/2010/Energy/17nov/Alley_Testimony.pdf|publisher=''[[United States House of Representatives]]''|accessdate=2010-12-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205065640/http://democrats.science.house.gov/Media/file/Commdocs/hearings/2010/Energy/17nov/Alley_Testimony.pdf|archivedate=2010-12-05|df=}}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.1114613 | pmid = 16239468 | title = Ice-Sheet and Sea-Level Changes | journal = Science | volume = 310 | issue = 5747 | pages = 456–60 | year = 2005 | last1 = Alley | first1 = R. B. | last2 = Clark | first2 = P. U. | last3 = Huybrechts | first3 = P | last4 = Joughin | first4 = I | bibcode = 2005Sci...310..456A }} Alley's 2007 testimony was due to his role as a lead author of "Chapter 4: Observations: Changes in Snow, Ice and Frozen Ground" for the Fourth Assessment Report of the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC). He has participated in the joint [[UN]]/[[WMO]] panel since 1992, having been a contributing author to both the second and third IPCC assessment reports. Alley has written several papers in the journals ''Nature ''and ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'',{{cite web|title=Dan and Carole Burack President's Distinguished Lecture Series|url=http://www.uvm.edu/president/DLS/alley.html|publisher=''[[University of Vermont]]''|accessdate=2008-09-30|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vJoQMosX?url=http://www.uvm.edu/president/DLS/alley.html|archivedate=2010-12-28|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.286.5442.1104| title = Northern Hemisphere Ice-Sheet Influences on Global Climate Change| journal = Science| volume = 286| issue = 5442| pages = 1104| year = 1999| last1 = Clark | first1 = P. U.}}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1029/97JC00269| title = The Greenland Ice Sheet Project 2 depth-age scale: Methods and results| journal = Journal of Geophysical Research| volume = 102| pages = 26411| year = 1997| last1 = Meese | first1 = D. A.| last2 = Gow | first2 = A. J.| last3 = Alley | first3 = R. B.| last4 = Zielinski | first4 = G. A.| last5 = Grootes | first5 = P. M.| last6 = Ram | first6 = M.| last7 = Taylor | first7 = K. C.| last8 = Mayewski | first8 = P. A.| last9 = Bolzan | first9 = J. F. | bibcode=1997JGR...10226411M }}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1029/97JC01283| title = Validity of the temperature reconstruction from water isotopes in ice cores| journal = Journal of Geophysical Research| volume = 102| pages = 26471| year = 1997| last1 = Jouzel | first1 = J.| last2 = Alley | first2 = R. B.| last3 = Cuffey | first3 = K. M.| last4 = Dansgaard | first4 = W.| last5 = Grootes | first5 = P.| last6 = Hoffmann | first6 = G.| last7 = Johnsen | first7 = S. J.| last8 = Koster | first8 = R. D.| last9 = Peel | first9 = D.| last10 = Shuman | first10 = C. A.| last11 = Stievenard | first11 = M.| last12 = Stuiver | first12 = M.| last13 = White | first13 = J. | bibcode=1997JGR...10226471J}}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.270.5235.455| title = Large Arctic Temperature Change at the Wisconsin-Holocene Glacial Transition| journal = Science| volume = 270| issue = 5235| pages = 455| year = 1995| last1 = Cuffey | first1 = K. M.| last2 = Clow | first2 = G. D.| last3 = Alley | first3 = R. B.| last4 = Stuiver | first4 = M.| last5 = Waddington | first5 = E. D.| last6 = Saltus | first6 = R. W.| bibcode = 1995Sci...270..455C}}{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1126/science.263.5154.1747| title = Changes in Atmospheric Circulation and Ocean Ice Cover over the North Atlantic During the Last 41,000 Years| journal = Science| volume = 263| issue = 5154| pages = 1747| year = 1994| last1 = Mayewski | first1 = P. A.| last2 = Meeker | first2 = L. D.| last3 = Whitlow | first3 = S.| last4 = Twickler | first4 = M. S.| last5 = Morrison | first5 = M. C.| last6 = Bloomfield | first6 = P.| last7 = Bond | first7 = G. C.| last8 = Alley | first8 = R. B.| last9 = Gow | first9 = A. J.| last10 = Meese | first10 = D. A.| last11 = Grootes | first11 = P. M.| last12 = Ram | first12 = M.| last13 = Taylor | first13 = K. C.| last14 = Wumkes | first14 = W. | pmid=17795382| bibcode = 1994Sci...263.1747M}} and chaired the [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]] on ''Abrupt Climate Change''. In 2000, he published the book ''The Two-Mile Time Machine: Ice Cores, Abrupt Climate Change, and Our Future''. He has appeared in numerous climate change-related television documentaries and has given many public presentations and media interviews about the subject.{{cite book|author=Richard Alley|title=EARTH: The Operators’ Manual|date=April 18, 2011|publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]]|isbn=978-0-393-08109-1}} {{cite book|author=Richard Alley|title=The Two-Mile Time Machine: Ice Cores, Abrupt Climate Change, and Our Future|date=July 1, 2002|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|isbn=978-0-691-10296-2}}{{cite book|author=Richard Alley|editor=[[Robert Bindschadler]]|title=The West Antarctic Ice Sheet: Behavior and Environment (Antarctic Research Series)|date=September 2000|publisher=[[American Geophysical Union]]|isbn=978-0-87590-957-8}}{{cite book|author=Richard Alley| title =Rocking the parks: Geological stories of the national parks| publisher = Kendall/Hunt Pub. Co| year = 1999| isbn = 978-0-7872-5706-4 }} Alley gave the Bjerknes lecture to the 2009 [[American Geophysical Union]] meeting titled "The biggest control knob- Carbon Dioxide in Earth's climate history". A video of the presentation{{cite web|title=Richard Alley lecture to the 2009 AGU "The biggest control knob- Carbon Dioxide in Earth's climate history" |url=http://www.agu.org/meetings/fm09/lectures/lecture_videos/A23A.shtml|publisher=''[[American Geophysical Union]]''|accessdate=2010-12-28}} is available (also available on YouTube). ==Awards and honors== Alley was awarded the [[Seligman Crystal]] in 2005 "for his prodigious contribution to our understanding of the stability of the ice sheets and glaciers of [[Antarctica]] and [[Greenland]], and of [[erosion]] and [[sedimentation]] by this moving ice." Alley is one of several Penn State earth scientists who are contributors to the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which shared the [[2007 Nobel Peace Prize]] with Al Gore. In 2005 he was also the first recipient of the Louis Agassiz Medal for his "outstanding and sustained contribution to glaciology and for his effective communication of important scientific issues in the public policy arena". His award citation stated "He is imaginative, sharp and humorous, and remains a thorn in the backside of the Bush administration."{{cite web|title=EGU Louis Agassiz Medallist 2006|url=http://www.cosis.net/members/meetings/sessions/information.php?p_id=207&s_id=3784|publisher=''[[European Geosciences Union]]''|accessdate=2008-09-28}} In 2008 Alley was elected to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]]. He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2010.{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780-2010: Chapter A|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterA.pdf|publisher=[[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]|accessdate=15 April 2011}} In 2011, he received the 17th Annual [[Heinz Award]] with a special focus on the environment.{{cite web|title=The Heinz Awards: Richard Alley|url=http://www.heinzawards.net/recipients/richard-alley|website=The Heinz Awards|publisher=The Heinz Awards|accessdate=August 26, 2016}}{{Cite news | last = Kalson | first = Sally | coauthors = | title = PSU professor's climate work wins 1 of 9 Heinz Awards | newspaper = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 2011-09-13 | url = http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/environment/psu-professors-climate-work-wins-1-of-9-heinz-awards-314518/#ixzz1XwTnKzGE | accessdate = 2013-05-17}} On 28 April 2014 the [[National Center for Science Education]] announced that its first annual Friend of the Planet award had been presented to Alley and [[Michael E. Mann]].{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = Friend of Darwin and Friend of the Planet awards for 2014 | url = http://ncse.com/news/2014/04/friend-darwin-friend-planet-awards-2014-0015556 | publisher = [[National Center for Science Education]] | date = 28 April 2014 | accessdate = 28 April 2014 }} He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society|Foreign Member of the Royal Society (ForMemRS)]] in the same year, his nomination reads: {{centered pull quote|Richard Alley has made outstanding contributions to the study of ice, its interactions with the landscape and its link to climate. He has made important advances in topics as diverse as grain-scale physics controlling ice deformation, the role and nature of ice streams, and processes at the bed of the ice sheet. His work synthesised the evidence that [[abrupt climate change]]s occurred in the past, and drove hypotheses about their cause and the role of ice on [[Ocean current|ocean circulation]]. Alley is also an outstanding science communicator, whose skill and enthusiasm has influenced both policymakers and large public audiences.{{cite web |url=https://royalsociety.org/people/fellowship/2014/richard-alley/ |title = Professor Richard Alley ForMemRS |publisher=The Royal Society |archivedate=2014-05-02 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502071729/https://royalsociety.org/people/fellowship/2014/richard-alley/ |location=London}}}} He won the 2014 [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]] in Climate Change category for his “pioneering research” into the “mechanics of ice and its implications for abrupt climate change,” in the words of the jury’s citation. He is the 2017 recipient of the [[Wollaston Medal]], which is the highest award given by the [[Geological Society of London]]. It is reserved for geologists who have made a significant impact on the field through a substantial body of impactful research. ==Television series== In addition to his research, Alley has made several appearances on television. On Sunday, April 10, 2011, [[PBS]] debuted a special program on climate change, entitled ''EARTH: The Operators’ Manual'',https://www.pbs.org/programs/earth-the-operators-manual/ hosted by Alley.http://www.earththeoperatorsmanual.com/host_richard_alley The program's aim was to present an objective, accessible assessment of the Earth’s problems and possible solutions, with the stated intention of leaving viewers informed, energized and optimistic. The series continued through 2012 on PBS and affiliates. The series is accompanied by a book of the same name, also by Richard Alley.http://earththeoperatorsmanual.com/products It was published on April 18, 2011. He has also appeared in episodes of the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] series ''[[Mega Disasters]]''.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [https://www.webcitation.org/5vJoQMosX?url=http://www.uvm.edu/president/DLS/alley.html Personal and academic information] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080517035013/http://www.geosc.psu.edu/documents/alley_seligman.pdf Award citation for Seligman Crystal] * [http://www.geosc.psu.edu/academic-faculty/alley-richard Penn State faculty page] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sfAswUeljQ0/ Richard Alley interviewed on ''Conversations from Penn State''] * [http://earththeoperatorsmanual.com/ Earth: The Operators' Manual TV Series website] * [https://www.pbs.org/programs/earth-the-operators-manual/ PBS Site] {{FRS 2014}} {{Authority control }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alley, Richard}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Glaciologists]] [[Category:Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change lead authors]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University faculty]] [[Category:ISI highly cited researchers]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Ohio State University alumni]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison alumni]] [[Category:Foreign Members of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Geophysical Union]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Association for the Advancement of Science]]

revision.text:
{{other uses of|SCAR}} {{Infobox organization | name = Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research | image = File:Scientific_Committee_on_Antarctic_Research_(logo).gif | image_border = | size = | alt = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | abbreviation = SCAR | motto = | formation = {{start date and age|1958}} | extinction = | type = [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]] | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = | region_served = Worldwide | membership = | language = English | leader_title = President | leader_name = | main_organ = | parent_organization = [[International Council for Science|International Council for Science (ICSU)]] | affiliations = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = {{URL|scar.org/}} }} The '''Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research''' ('''SCAR''') is an interdisciplinary body of the [[International Council for Science|International Council for Science (ICSU)]]. [[File:Sunny Skies over the Antarctic Peninsula - NASA Earth Observatory.jpg|thumb|The calving front at the [[Scar Inlet|SCAR Inlet]] is named for the '''Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research''.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://data.antarctica.gov.au/aadc/gaz/display_name.cfm?gaz_id=131248|title = Scar Inlet|date = |accessdate = |website = data.antarctica.gov.au|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> It is the remaining fragment of the much larger [[Larsen B]] ice shelf which disintegrated in 2002.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-09-11/glacial-death-watch-why-an-ice-shelf-snapped-in-2002-and-what-s-coming-next|title=Glacial Death Watch: Why an Ice Shelf Snapped in 2002 and What's Coming Next|last=Roston|first=Eric|website=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=2015-12-21}}</ref> |260x260px]]
==History== It was established in February 1958 to continue the international coordination of Antarctic scientific activities that had begun during the [[International Geophysical Year]] of 1957-58.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research|url = http://dels.nas.edu/global/prb/scar|website = dels.nas.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-21}}</ref> SCAR is charged with the initiating, developing and coordinating of scientific research in the [[Antarctic]] region.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.icsu.org/what-we-do/interdisciplinary-bodies/scar|title=Antarctic Research (SCAR)|website=www.icsu.org|language=en|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> The scientific business of SCAR is conducted by its Standing Scientific Groups. SCAR also provides scientific advice to the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meetings and other organizations on issues of science and conservation affecting the management of Antarctica and the [[Southern Ocean]]. In that role, SCAR has made numerous recommendations on a variety of matters, very few of which have been incorporated into [[Antarctic Treaty]] instruments.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gramling|first=Carolyn|date=2015-08-11|title=Report sets new goals for U.S. Antarctic Program|url=http://news.sciencemag.org/earth/2015/08/report-sets-new-goals-u-s-antarctic-program|journal=Science|doi=10.1126/science.aad1602}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kennicutt|first=Mahlon C.|last2=Chown|first2=Steven L.|last3=Cassano|first3=John J.|last4=Liggett|first4=Daniela|last5=Massom|first5=Rob|last6=Peck|first6=Lloyd S.|last7=Rintoul|first7=Steve R.|last8=Storey|first8=John W. V.|last9=Vaughan|first9=David G.|date=2014-08-07|title=Polar research: Six priorities for Antarctic science|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/512023a|journal=Nature|volume=512|issue=7512|pages=23–25|doi=10.1038/512023a|pmid=25100467}}</ref>
==Activities== SCAR meets every two years to conduct its administrative business at the SCAR Delegates Meeting. An executive committee elected from the delegates is responsible for the day-to-day administration of SCAR through its secretariat at the [[Scott Polar Research Institute]] in [[Cambridge]], England. The executive committee comprises the president and four vice-presidents. The SCAR Secretariat is staffed by the executive director, executive officer and an administrative assistant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/members-and-officers/secretariat|title=SCAR Secretariat|website=www.scar.org|access-date=2017-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620021339/http://www.scar.org/members-and-officers/secretariat|archivedate=2017-06-20|df=}}</ref>
SCAR also holds, prior to the delegates meeting, a major open science conference to draw attention to Antarctic issues, along with meetings of the standing scientific groups that are designed to finalize the science programmes for eventual approval by the delegates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/scarmeetings/conferences|title=SCAR Meetings and Conferences|website=www.scar.org|access-date=2017-06-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170619183530/http://www.scar.org/scarmeetings/conferences|archivedate=2017-06-19|df=}}</ref>
In 2002 SCAR received the prestigious [[Prince of Asturias Award]] for International Cooperation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fpa.es/en/princess-of-asturias-awards/laureates/2002-the-scientific-committee-on-antarctic-research.html?especifica=0&idCategoria=0&anio=2002&especifica=0|title=The Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research - Laureates|last=|first=|date=2002|website=The Princess of Asturias Foundation|publisher=The Princess of Asturias Foundation|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/download.php?file=%2FPOL%2FPOL38_207%2FS0032247400018192a.pdf&code=065691d6f01d66255eecd461067b11c3|title=A Major International Prize for SCAR|last=|first=|date=2002|work=SCAR-COMNAP Joint Committee|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
== SCAR medals == Since 2006, SCAR has awarded three medals biennially in recognition of excellence in Antarctic and Southern Ocean research and outstanding service to the international Antarctic community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/awards/medals|title=Medals|last=|first=|website=www.scar.org|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> There is one medal for Excellence in Antarctic Research, one for International Scientific Coordination, and the SCAR President's medal for Outstanding Achievement. Presentations are made at the SCAR Open Science Conference and are intended to reward those who exemplify the best of the Antarctic community and serve as role models for the next generation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/2015/55-awards|archive-url=https://archive.is/20161026073206/http://www.scar.org/2015/55-awards|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-10-26|title=Awards|website=www.scar.org|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Composite Gazetteer of Antarctica]] * [[Anna Wåhlin]], committee co-chair
==References== {{Reflist|35em}}
==External links== *[http://www.scar.org/ Official website]
