Macpherson (tennis)|David Macpherson]] * [[Alex Cisak]], [[Association football]] player currently playing for [[Football League 2]] side [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]]. Although, he was born in [[Poland]]. * [[Royce Hart]], [[Australian rules football]]er * [[Matthew Richardson (footballer)|Matthew Richardson]], Australian rules footballer * Former [[V8 Supercar]] and current [[NASCAR]] driver [[Marcos Ambrose]] (2003–2004 champion of V8 Supercar) * Retired [[V8 Supercar]], driver [[John Bowe (racing driver)|John Bowe]] (1995 champion) * Cyclist [[Richie Porte]] * Cyclist [[Luke Ockerby]] ===Musicians and composers=== * Musician [[Courtney Barnett]] (born in [[Sydney]]; however, she moved to [[Hobart]] with her family at age sixteen, attending [[St Michael's Collegiate School]] and later, the [[University of Tasmania|Tasmanian School of Art]]) * Drummer [[Dave Haley]] from technical death metal band [[Psycroptic]] and black metal band [[Ruins (metal band)]] * Composer [[Don Kay (composer)|Don Kay]] * Country music singer [[Jean Stafford (musician)|Jean Stafford]] * Composer [[Peter Sculthorpe]] * Band [[Luca Brasi (band)]][[Luca Brasi (band)]]{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=June 2018}} * Bassist [[Brian Ritchie]], founding member of [[Violent Femmes]] * Musician Russell Menzies (Sin Nanna) of one-man black metal band [[Striborg]] {{Div col end}} ==Gallery== File:Cataract Gorge Tasmania.jpg|Cataract Gorge, Tasmania File:Antarctic Garden Hobart BG.jpg|Sub-Antarctic Garden, Royal Tasmanian Botanical Garden, Hobart File:Mt Roland, Tasmania, Australia.jpg|Mount Roland ==See also== {{wikipedia books|Australia}} * [[Aboriginal Tasmanians]] * [[Australia]] * [[Index of Australia-related articles]] * [[List of amphibians of Tasmania]] * [[List of schools in Tasmania]] * [[Outline of Australia]] * [[Protected areas of Tasmania]] * [[Regions of Tasmania]] * [[University of Tasmania]] {{portal bar|Islands|Oceania|Commonwealth realms|Australia|Tasmania}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite book |title=The Companion to Tasmanian History |editor1-last=Alexander |editor1-first= Alison |year=2005 |publisher=Centre for Tasmanian Historical Studies, University of Tasmania |location=Hobart, Tasmania |isbn=1-86295-223-X |url=http://www.utas.edu.au/library/companion_to_tasmanian_history/ |oclc=61888464}} * Robson, L. L. (1983). ''A History of Tasmania. Volume I. Van Diemen's Land from the Earliest Times to 1855''. Melbourne: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-554364-5}}. * Robson, L. L. (1991). ''A History of Tasmania. Volume II. Colony and State from 1856 to the 1980s''. Melbourne: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-553031-4}}. ==External links== {{Commons}} {{wikivoyage}} * [http://tas.gov.au/ Tasmania Online—the main State Government website] * [http://www.discovertasmania.com/ Discover Tasmania] – official tourism website * {{osmrelation|2369652}} {{Tasmania}} {{States and territories of Australia}} {{Australia topics}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=April 2013}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Tasmania| ]] [[Category:Islands of Australia]] [[Category:Islands of Oceania]] [[Category:States and territories of Australia]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1825]] [[Category:1825 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:1642 in the Dutch Empire]]

{{Infobox book | name = The Last Summer of Reason | image = The Last Summer of Reason (book cover).jpg | caption = | author = [[Tahar Djaout]] | title_orig = | translator = Marjolijn de Jagar | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = [[French language|French]] | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Ruminator Press]] | pub_date = 1999 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 978-1886913509 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Last Summer of Reason''''' ({{Lang-fr|'''Le Dernier Été de la raison'''}}) is a novel by [[Algeria]]n writer [[Tahar Djaout]]. It was originally written and published in [[French language|French]]. The English translation was produced by [[Marjolijn de Jagar]], and published by [[Ruminator Press]] in 2001, with a foreword by [[Wole Soyinka]]. The novel was published [[Posthumous work|posthumously]].
==Plot==
Boualem Yekker is a bookseller in a country probably modelled on Algeria. His home is firmly in the grip of religious [[Fundamentalism|fundamentalists]], but only recently: it was once a republic, but now it is a "Community in the Faith". Djaout presents readers with a terrifying world of religious fundamentalism comparable to [[George Orwell|Orwell]]'s 1984, but substituting a religious dictatorship for a purely political one.
At first Yekker is only on the periphery of danger. He is "neither elegant nor talented", which puts him out of the spotlight: "what is persecuted above all, and more than people's opinions, is their ability to create and propagate beauty." Still, Yekker is a purveyor of these outrageous "idea- and beauty-filled objects" known as books, so he doesn't fit in too well in this new, retrograde society.
Business isn't exactly booming, of course. Touchingly Djaout describes Yekker's brief moments of hope when he sees people gazing in the shop window. But there is hardly a market for the sorts of books he has any longer. One acquaintance, Ali Elbouliga, still comes to while away time there. Otherwise, Yekker remains largely alone in his bookish world—and the books ultimately prove almost as much a burden as a solace.
Family life also gets more complicated when his daughter turns on him. "The illness of fanaticism had attacked her." She is transformed, "covered with superior certainties".
Yekker tries to continue to live his life in the manner he is accustomed to, but there is no escape from the encroaching fanaticism. It crushes all opposition. Any semblance of rationality is done away with. Even weather forecasts are banned, as if these called some all-mighty's grand plan (and his power) into question. (What a pathetic god it must be they're protecting, if he can be threatened by mortals' barely educated guesses at tomorrow's weather; doesn't the fact that the meteorologists barely ever get it right instead reinforce the idea of divine omnipotence?)
Imagination is dulled, "the world has become aphasic, opaque, and sullen; it is wearing mourning clothes." Books "constitute the safest refuge against this world of horror" all around Yekker, but the books are also a danger to him. Eventually they must make place for "the one, the irremovable Book of resigned certainty."
The threats against Yekker mount. What is, at first, almost harmless child's play intensifies to very real danger. Might conquers right:
They have understood the danger in words, all the words they cannot manage to domesticate and anesthetize. For words, put end to end, bring doubt and change. Words above all must not conceive of the utopia of another form of truth, of unsuspected paths, of another place of thought.
==External links== * Article: "Islamists Killed Tahar Djaout: We Should Give Life to His Ideas," by Jennifer Bryson, January 16, 2009, [https://web.archive.org/web/20090130064649/http://thepublicdiscourse.com/viewarticle.php?selectedarticle=2009.01.16.001.pdart The Public Discourse]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Last Summer of Reason, The}} [[Category:2001 novels]] [[Category:Algerian novels]] [[Category:Novels published posthumously]] [[Category:French-language novels]]

[[File:Emanuel Gottlieb Leutze - Columbus Before the Queen.JPG|thumb|right|300px|''Columbus before the Queen'', imagined by [[Emanuel Gottlieb Leutze]], 1843]] The following timeline covers European exploration from 1418 to 1957.
The 15th century witnessed the rounding of the feared [[Cape Bojador]] and Portuguese exploration of the west coast of Africa, while in the last decade of the century the Spanish sent expeditions to the New World, focusing on exploring the [[Caribbean Sea]], and the Portuguese discovered the sea route to India. In the 16th century, various countries sent exploring parties into the interior of the Americas, as well as to their respective west and east coasts north to California and Labrador and south to Chile and Tierra del Fuego. In the 17th century, the Russians explored and conquered Siberia in search of sables, while the Dutch roughly worked on the chart for Australia. The 18th century saw the first extensive exploration of the South Pacific and the discovery of Alaska, while the nineteenth was dominated by exploration of the polar regions (not to mention excursions into the heart of Africa). By the 20th century, the poles themselves had been reached.
==15th century== [[File:Vascodagama.JPG|thumb|Vasco da Gama lands at [[Calicut]], illustration for Os Lusíadas, 1880 by Ernesto Casanova.]] *1418 – [[João Gonçalves Zarco]] and [[Tristão Vaz Teixeira]] discover [[Porto Santo]].<ref name=Diffie>{{cite book | last = Diffie | first = Bailey | title = Foundations of the Portuguese Empire, 1415–1580 | publisher = University of Minnesota Press | year = 1977 | location = | isbn = 0-8166-0782-6 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vtZtMBLJ7GgC&lpg=1 | pages = 465–474}}</ref> *1419 – [[João Gonçalves Zarco|Gonçalves]] and Vaz discover [[Madeira]].<ref name=Diffie/> *1427 – [[Diogo de Silves]] discovers the [[Azores]].<ref name=Diffie/> *1434 – [[Gil Eanes]] passes [[Cape Chaunar|Cabo de Não]] and rounds [[Cape Bojador]].<ref name=Morison1974>{{cite book | last = Morison | first = Samuel | title = The European Discovery of America: The Southern Voyages, 1492–1616 | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 1974 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1444 – [[Dinis Dias]] reaches the mouth of the [[Senegal River]].<ref name=Whitfield/> *1446 – The [[Portugal|Portuguese]] reach [[Cape Verde]] and the [[Gambia River]].<ref name=Whitfield/> *1456 – [[Alvise Cadamosto]] and [[Diogo Gomes]] explored the [[Cape Verde Islands]].<ref name=Diffie/> *1460 – [[Pêro de Sintra]] reaches [[Sierra Leone]].<ref name=Diffie/> *1470 – [[Cape Palmas]] is passed.<ref name=Whitfield/> *1472 – [[Fernão do Pó]] discovers [[Bioko]].<ref name=Ravenstein>{{cite book | last = Ravenstein | first = Ernest George | title = The voyages of Diogo Cão and Bartholomeu Dias, 1482–88 | publisher = W. Clowes and Sons | year = 1900 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qt-fAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Voyages+of+Diogo+C%C3%A3o&hl=en&ei=kjs-TO-IDsGqlAe-gNn3BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1473 – [[Lopo Gonçalves]] is the first to cross the [[equator]].<ref name=Whitfield/><ref name=Ravenstein/> *1474–75 – Ruy de Sequeira discovers [[São Tomé and Príncipe]].<ref name=Ravenstein/> *1482 – [[Diogo Cão]] reaches the [[Congo River]], where he erects a "padrão" (pillar of stone).<ref name=Ravenstein/> *1485–86 – Cão reaches [[Cape Cross]], where he erects his last padrão.<ref name=Ravenstein/> *1487–92 – [[Pêro da Covilhã]] travels to Arabia, down to the mouth of the Red Sea, eastward by sail to the [[Malabar Coast]] (visiting [[Kozhikode|Calicut]] and [[Goa]]); later sails down the east coast of Africa (visiting the trading stations of [[Mombasa]], [[Zanzibar]], and [[Sofala]]); on his return he visits [[Mecca]] and [[Medina]] before reaching [[Ethiopia]] in search of the mythical [[Prester John]].<ref name=Fleming2004>{{cite book | last = Fleming | first = Fergus | title = Off the Map: Tales of Endurance and Exploration | publisher = Atlantic Monthly Press | year = 2004 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1488 – [[Bartolomeu Dias]] rounds the "Cape of Storms" ([[Cape of Good Hope]]).<ref name=Ravenstein/> *1492 – [[Christopher Columbus]] discovers the [[Bahamas]], [[Cuba]], and "Española" ([[Hispaniola]]).<ref name=Taviani>{{cite book| last = Taviani| first = Paulo| title = Columbus: The Great Adventure, His Life, His Times, and His Voyages| publisher = Random House| year = 1991| location = New York| page = }}</ref> *1493–94 – Columbus discovers [[Dominica]] and [[Guadeloupe]], among other islands of the [[Lesser Antilles]]; also discovers [[Puerto Rico]] and [[Jamaica]].<ref name=Taviani/> *1497 – [[John Cabot]] discovers [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]].<ref name=Morison>{{cite book | last = Morison | first = Samuel | title = The European Discovery of America: The Northern Voyages | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 1971 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1497–98 – [[Vasco da Gama]] sails to [[India]] and back.<ref name=Whitfield>{{cite book | last = Whitfield | first = Peter | title = New Found Lands: Maps in the History of Exploration | publisher = Routledge | year = 1998 | location = | page = }}</ref> *1498 – Columbus discovers the mainland of [[South America]].<ref name=Taviani/> *1499 – [[Alonso de Ojeda]] explores the South American mainland from about [[Cayenne]] (in modern [[French Guiana]]) to [[Cabo de la Vela]] (in modern [[Colombia]]), discovering the mouths of the [[Orinoco River|Orinoco]] and entering [[Lake Maracaibo]].<ref name=Morison1974/> *1499 – [[Amerigo Vespucci]] discovers the mouth of the [[Amazon River]] and reaches 6°S, in present-day northern [[Brazil]].<ref name=Pohl1966>{{cite book | last = Pohl | first = Frederick J. | title = Amerigo Vespucci: Pilot Major | publisher = Octagon Books | year = 1966 | location = New York | pages = 54, 55 }}</ref> *1499 – [[João Fernandes Lavrador|João Fernandes ''Lavrador'']], together with [[Pêro de Barcelos]], sight [[Labrador]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Diffie|first=Bailey|title=Prelude to empire: Portugal overseas before Henry the Navigator|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|year=1960|isbn=0-8032-5049-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IjBfEorbZWAC&lpg|ref=Diffie 1960|pages=463–464}}</ref> *1499 – [[Gaspar Corte-Real|Gaspar]] and [[Miguel Corte-Real]] reach and map [[Greenland]].<ref name="ReferenceA">[[#Diffie 1977|Diffie 1977]], pp. 464–465.</ref>
==16th century== [[File:Nau de Pedro Álvares Cabral.jpg|thumb|alt=An old painting depicting a wooden sailing ship with sails full blown by the wind||Cabral's ship on the fleet that sighted the Brazilian mainland for the first time on 22 April 1500. From the manuscript ''Memória das Armadas que de Portugal passaram à Índia'']] [[File:Balboa südsee.jpg|thumb|Balboa claiming possession of the Mar del Sur ("South Sea").]] [[File:Tenochtitlan y Golfo de Mexico 1524.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Map of the island city [[Tenochtitlán]] and Mexico gulf made by one of Cortés' men, 1524, [[Newberry Library]], Chicago]] [[File:Discovery of the Mississippi.jpg|thumb|''Discovery of the Mississippi'' by [[William H. Powell]] (1823–1879) is a [[Romanticism|Romantic]] depiction of de Soto seeing the Mississippi River for the first time. It hangs in the [[United States Capitol rotunda]].]] [[File:Coronado-Remington.jpg|thumb|right|Coronado Sets Out to the North, by [[Frederic Remington]], 1861–1909]] [[File:Cabrillo National Monument (Loki30).jpg|thumb|The [[Cabrillo National Monument]] in San Diego, California]] [[File:Polar bear, Gerrit de Veer (1596).jpg|thumb|Crew of [[Willem Barentsz]] fighting a [[polar bear]], 1596]]
*1500 – [[Vicente Yáñez Pinzón]] reaches the northeast coast of what today is Brazil at a cape he names "Santa Maria de la Consolación" ([[Cabo de Santo Agostinho]]) and sails fifty miles up a river he names the "Marañón" ([[Amazon River|Amazon]]).<ref name=Morison1974/> *1500 – [[Pedro Álvares Cabral]] makes the "official" discovery of Brazil,<ref name=Morison1974/> leading the first [[2nd Portuguese India Armada (Cabral, 1500)|expedition]] that united Europe, America, Africa, and Asia.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=hBTqPX4G9Y4C&pg=PA187&dq=Cabral+four+continents&hl=pt-PT&sa=X&ei=zPIIU8HvE-af7AakkYDICw&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Cabral%20four%20continents&f=false] ''Foundations of the Portuguese Empire, 1415-1580'', Bailey Wallys Diffie and George D. Winius - Page 187, University of Minnesota Press, 1977</ref><ref>[https://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200504/the.coming.of.the.portuguese.htm] ''The Coming of the Portuguese'' by Paul Lunde, London University’s School of Oriental and African Studies, in Saudi Aramco World - July/August 2005 Volume 56, Number 4,</ref> *1500 – [[João Fernandes Lavrador|João Fernandes]] reaches [[Cape Farewell, Greenland|Cape Farewell]], [[Greenland]] ("Terra do Lavrador", or Land of the Husbandman).<ref name=Morison/> *1500–02 – Gaspar and Miguel Corte Real discover and name the coasts of "Terra Verde" (likely Newfoundland) and Labrador.<ref name=Morison/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> *1500-01 – [[Diogo Dias]] discovers [[Madagascar]] and reaches the gate of the [[Red Sea]], the [[Bab-el-Mandeb]] Strait.<ref name=Morison1974/> *1500 – [[Rodrigo de Bastidas]] explores the Colombian coast from Cabo de la Vela to the [[Gulf of Urabá]].<ref name=Morison1974/> *1501-02 – [[Gonçalo Coelho]] discovers "Rio de Janeiro" ([[Guanabara Bay]]).<ref name=Morison1974/> *1502–03 – Columbus explores the [[North America]]n mainland from [[Guanaja]] off modern [[Honduras]] to the present-day border of [[Panama]] and [[Colombia]].<ref name=Morison1974/><ref name=Taviani/> *1505 – [[Juan de Bermúdez]] discovers [[Bermuda]].<ref name=Morison1974/> *1506 – [[Lourenço de Almeida]] reaches the [[Maldives]] and [[Sri Lanka]].<ref>Ferguson, D. W. ''The discovery of Ceylon by the Portuguese in 1506'' (Journal of the Ceylon Asiatic Society, vol. xix, no. 59, 1907, pp. 284–384).</ref> *1506 – [[Tristão da Cunha]] discovers the island of [[Tristan da Cunha]]. {{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} *1509 – [[Diogo Lopes de Sequeira]] reaches [[Sumatra]] and [[Malacca]].<ref name=Marsden>{{cite book | last = Marsden | first = William | title = The history of Sumatra: containing an account of the government, laws, customs, and manners of the native inhabitants, with a description of the natural productions, and a relation to the ancient political state of that island. | publisher = J. McCreery | year = 1811 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4hs7QCwhQakC&pg=PA406&dq=Diogo+Lopes+de+Sequeira+Sumatra&hl=en&ei=qh1aTOHDJo-8sQOU-6X1Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1511 – [[Duarte Fernandes]] leads a diplomatic mission to [[Ayutthaya Kingdom]] (Siam or [[Thailand]]).<ref name=Lach>{{cite book | last = Lach | first = Donald F. | title = Asia in the Making of Europe, Volume I: The Century of Discovery | publisher = University of Chicago Press | year = 1994 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iWorvZ17qcoC&lpg=1 | isbn = 0-226-46731-7 | page = 520}}</ref> *1511 – Rui Nunes da Cunha leads a diplomatic mission to [[Pegu]] (Burma or [[Myanmar]]).<ref name=Lach/><ref name=Galvano>{{cite book | last = Galvano | first = Antonio Galvano | title = The Discoveries of the World from Their First Original unto the Year of Our Lord 1555 | publisher = BiblioBazaar, LLC | year = 2009 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=o6wy0K0HX7cC&lpg=PA114&ots=A5R4LUdPfd&dq=Rui%20Nunes%20da%20Cunha%20pegu&pg=PA114#v=onepage&q&f=false | isbn = 1-113-68747-9 | page = 114}}</ref> *1511–12 – [[João de Lisboa]] and Estevão de Fróis discover the "Cape of Santa Maria" ([[Punta Del Este]]) in the [[Rio de La Plata|River Plate]], exploring its estuary, and traveling as far south as the [[Gulf of San Matias]] at 42ºS, in present-day [[Uruguay]] and [[Argentina]] (penetrating {{convert|300|km|0|abbr=on}} "around the Gulf").<ref>[http://biblio.wdfiles.com/local--files/schuller-1915-nova/schuller_1915_nova.pdf Newen Zeytung auss Presillg Landt]</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Bethell | first = Leslie | title = The Cambridge History of Latin America, Volume 1, Colonial Latin America | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1984 | location = Cambridge | pages = 257 }}[https://books.google.com/books?hl=pt-PT&id=_w0kAPYQ5xMC&q=froes#v=onepage&q=1511&f=false]</ref> *1511–12 – [[António de Abreu]] sails through the [[Strait of Malacca]], between Sumatra and [[Bangka Island|Bangka]], and along the coasts of [[Java]], [[Bali]], [[Lombok]], [[Sumbawa]], and [[Flores]] to the "Spice Islands" ([[Maluku Islands|Maluku]]).<ref>{{cite book|first=Armando|last=Cortesão|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h82D-Y0E3TwC&lpg=PR81&dq=Simao%20Afonso%20Bisagudo&pg=PR81#v=onepage&q=Simao%20Afonso%20Bisagudo&f=false|title=The Suma Oriental of Tomé Pires: an account of the east, from the Red Sea to Japan, written in Malacca and India in 1512–1515/The Book of Francisco Rodrigues rutter of a voyage in the Red Sea, nautical rules, almanack and maps, written and drawn in the east before 1515|publisher=The [[Hakluyt Society]]|year=1944}}</ref> *1513 – [[Jorge Álvares]] lands off the coast of [[China]], on [[Nei Lingding Island]] at the [[Pearl River Delta]].<ref name=Diffie/> *1513 – [[Vasco Núñez de Balboa]] crosses the [[Isthmus of Panama]] and reaches the [[Bay of San Miguel]], discovering the "Mar del Sur" ([[Pacific Ocean]]).<ref name=Morison1974/> *1513 – [[Juan Ponce de León]] discovers "La Florida" ([[Florida]]) and the [[Yucatan Peninsula|Yucatan]].<ref name=Morison1974/> *1514–15 – António Fernandes reaches present-day [[Zimbabwe]].<ref name=Russell-Wood>{{cite book | last = Russell-Wood | first = A. J. R. | title = The Portuguese empire, 1415–1808: a world on the move. | publisher = Johns Hopkins University Press | year = 1998 | location = Baltimore, MD | url = https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JTVH7PZU1hUC&oi=fnd&pg=PP7&ots=6EuQ7TTXzg&sig=tcHT6EAVDsq_9Ru_4GUcz_7KtOI#v=onepage&q=Zimbabwe&f=false}}</ref> *1515 – Gonzalo de Badajoz crosses the Isthmus of Panama at the site of [[Nombre de Dios, Colón|Nombre de Dios]], reaching as far as the interior of the [[Azuero Peninsula]].<ref name=Bancroft>{{cite book | last = Bancroft | first = Hubert Howe | title = History of Central America | publisher = A. L. Bancroft | year = 1882 | location = San Francisco | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Bm8LAQAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+Central+America&hl=en&ei=xfeoTP7GDpOmsQPp-7jeDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1516 – [[Juan Díaz de Solís]] explores the River Plate estuary and names it "La Mar Dulce" ("The Fresh-Water Sea").<ref name=Morison1974/> *1516 – Portuguese traders land in [[Da Nang]], [[Champa]], naming it [[Cochinchina]] (modern [[Vietnam]]).<ref name=Li>{{cite book | last = Li | first = Tana Li | title = Nguyễn Cochinchina: southern Vietnam in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries | publisher = SEAP Publications | year = 1998 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=05x5UGA8MmAC&lpg=PA72&dq=Cochin%20China%20name%20portuguese%201516&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q&f=false | isbn = 0-87727-722-2 | page = 72}}</ref><ref name=Yule>{{cite book | last = Yule | first = Sir Henry Yule, A. C. Burnell, William Crooke | title = A glossary of colloquial Anglo-Indian words and phrases: Hobson-Jobson | publisher = Routledge | year = 1995 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=20pdFRekGvMC&lpg=PA226&ots=9memaoeVIA&dq=cochin%20China%201516%20portuguese&pg=PA226#v=onepage&q=cochin%20China%201516%20portuguese&f=false | isbn = 0-7007-0321-7 | page = 34}}</ref> *1518 – Lourenço Gomes reaches [[Borneo]].<ref name=Keane>{{cite book | last = Keane | first = A. H. | title = Eastern geography: a geography of the Malay peninsula, Indo-China, the Eastern archipelago, the Philippines, and New Guinea. | publisher = E. Stanford | year = 1892 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=3HNKAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA139&dq=Lorenzo+de+Gomez+New+Guinea+1518&hl=en&ei=EfhVTJK_MJDGsAP74u3WAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1518 – [[Juan de Grijalva]] explores the [[Mexico|Mexican]] coast from "Patouchan" ([[Champotón, Campeche|Champotón]]) to just north of the [[Pánuco River]].<ref name=Morison1974/> *1519 – [[Hernán Cortés]] travels from [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Villa Rica de la Vera Cruz]] to the [[Aztec]] capital of [[Tenochtitlan]] on [[Lake Texcoco]].<ref name=Marks>{{cite book | last = Marks | first = Richard Lee | title = Cortés: the Great Adventurer and the Fate of Aztec Mexico | publisher = Knopf | year = 1993 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1519 – [[Alonzo Alvarez de Pineda]] sails around the [[Gulf of Mexico]] to the Pánuco, proving its insularity; also discovers the "Father of Waters" (the [[Mississippi River|Mississippi]]).<ref name=Morison1974/> *1519 – [[Gaspar de Espinosa]] sails west along the west coasts of modern [[Panama]] and [[Costa Rica]] as far as the [[Gulf of Nicoya]].<ref name=Bancroft/> *1519–22 – [[Ferdinand Magellan]]'s expedition completes the first circumnavigation of the [[globe]], exploring the coast of [[Patagonia]] and discovering and traversing the [[Strait of Magellan]].<ref name=Bergreen>{{cite book | last = Bergreen | first = Laurence | title = Over the Edge of the World: Magellan's Terrifying Circumnavigation of the Globe | publisher = William Morrow | year = 2003 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1520–21 – [[João Alvares Fagundes]] explores [[Burgeo, Newfoundland and Labrador|Burgeo]] and [[Saint Pierre and Miquelon]] in Newfoundland, and [[Nova Scotia]].<ref>Ganong, W. F., ''Crucial Maps in the Early Cartography and Place-Nomenclature of the Atlantic Coast of Canada'', with an introduction, commentary and map notes by Theodore E. Layng (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1964), Chapter II: "João Àlvares Fagundes," 45-97.</ref><ref name="Francisco de Souza1570">{{cite book | last = Souza | first = Francisco | title = Tratado das ilhas novas e descombrimento dellas e outras couzas | publisher = University of Harvard, Archivo dos Açores | year = 1884 | location = University of Harvard | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=3WMDAAAAQAAJ&redir_esc=y}}</ref> *1521 – Francisco Gordillo and Pedro de Quexos find the mouth of a river they name "Rio de San Juan Bautista" (perhaps [[Winyah Bay]] at the mouth of the [[Pee Dee River]] in modern [[South Carolina]]).<ref name=Hayes>{{cite book | last = Hayes | first = Derek | title = America Discovered: A Historical Atlas of North American Exploration | publisher = Douglas & McIntyre | year = 2004 | location = Vancouver | page = }}</ref> *1521 – [[Cristóvão Jacques]] explores the Plate River and discovers the [[Parana River]], entering it for about 23 leagues (around 140 km), to near the present city of [[Rosario, Santa Fe|Rosario]].<ref name="Johson/Silva">{{cite book | last = John/Silva | first = Harold/Maria Beatriz Nizza da | title = Nova História da Expansão Portuguesa (direcção de Joel Serrão e A. H. de Oliveira Marques)- O Império Luso-brasileiro (1500-1620), vol. VI | publisher = Editorial Presença | year = 1992 | location = Lisboa |pages=114–170.}}</ref> *1522 – [[Gil González Dávila]] explores inland from the Gulf of Nicoya, discovering [[Lake Nicaragua]], while his pilot [[Andrés Niño]] explores along the coast to the west, discovering the [[Gulf of Fonseca]] and perhaps reaching as far as the southwestern coast of modern [[Guatemala]].<ref name=Bancroft/> *1524 – [[Giovanni da Verrazzano]] explores the eastern seaboard of the present [[United States]] from about [[Cape Fear (headland)|Cape Fear]] to [[Maine]]; discovers the mouth of the [[Hudson River]].<ref name=Morison/> *c. 1524 – [[Aleixo Garcia]] travels westward from [[Santa Catarina (island)|Santa Catarina]], across the [[Paraná River|Paraná]] (perhaps sighting [[Iguazu Falls]]) to the [[Paraguay]] near the site of [[Asunción]], then across the [[Gran Chaco]] to the [[Andes]] and the [[Inca Empire|Inca frontier]], somewhere between [[Mizque]] and [[Tomina Province|Tomina]] in modern [[Bolivia]].<ref name=Goodman/> *1524–25 – [[Francisco Pizarro]] and [[Diego de Almagro]] explore from Punta Piña (7° 56’ N) on the southern coast of Panama to the [[San Juan River (Colombia)|San Juan River]] (4° N), on the west coast of Colombia.<ref name=Prescott>{{cite book | last = Prescott | first = William H. | title = History of the Conquest of Peru | publisher = John B. Aldan | year = 1890 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=k_QqAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA122&dq=Francisco+Pizarro&hl=en&ei=UVajTLmMMYKesQOW7Nn6Bg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFIQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref> *1525 – [[Estêvão Gomes]] probes [[Penobscot Bay]], [[Maine]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1525 – The Portuguese reach "Celebes" ([[Sulawesi]]).<ref>Crawfurd, J. 1856. ''A descriptive dictionary of the Indian islands and adjacent countries.'' London: Bradbury & Evans.</ref> *1525 – Diogo da Rocha and [[Gomes de Sequeira]] discover the [[Caroline Islands]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Galvano|first=Antonio |title=The Discoveries of the World from Their First Original Unto the Year of Our Lord 1555, issued by the Hakluyt Society|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|year=1563–2004 reissue|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XivHTiZoMycC&lpg=1|isbn=0-7661-9022-6 |ref=Galvano 1563|authorlink=António Galvão|page=168}}</ref> *1526 – [[Alonso de Salazar]] discovers the [[Marshall Islands]] ([[Bokak Atoll]]).<ref name=Quanchi>{{cite book | last = Quanchi | first = Max, and John Robson | title = Historical dictionary of the discovery and exploration of the Pacific Islands | publisher = Scarecrow Press | year = 2005 | location = Lanham, Md. | url = }}</ref> *1526–28 – Pizarro and his pilot Bartolomé Ruiz explore the west coast of South America from the San Juan River south to the [[Santa River]] (about 9° S), becoming the first to sight the coasts of [[Ecuador]] and [[Peru]].<ref name=Prescott/> *1526–27 – [[Jorge de Menezes]] discovers [[New Guinea]].<ref name=Whiteway>{{cite book | last = Whiteway | first = Richard Stephen | title = The rise of Portuguese power in India, 1497–1550. | publisher = A. Constable | year = 1899 | location = Westminster | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jM4NAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA333&dq=Jorge+de+Menezes+New+Guinea&hl=en&ei=aPNVTK2-DY_SsAOX76jaAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1527–28 – [[Sebastian Cabot (explorer)|Sebastian Cabot]] explores several hundred miles up the Paraná River, past its confluence with the Paraguay.<ref name=Morison1974/> *1528 – [[Diogo Rodrigues]] explores the [[Mascarene Islands]] (which he names after [[Pedro Mascarenhas]]), naming the islands of [[Réunion]], [[Mauritius]], and [[Rodrigues (island)|Rodrigues]].<ref name=Fonseca>{{cite book | last = Fonseca | first = José Nicolau da | title = An historical and archaeological sketch of the city of Goa: preceded by a short statistical account of the territory of Goa | publisher = Asian Educational Services {{ISBN|81-206-0207-2}} | year = 1994 | location = New Delhi | page = }}</ref> *1528–36 – [[Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca]] and three others are the only survivors of a group of several hundred colonists who travel from the coast of western Florida to the Rio Sinaloa in northern Mexico, where they encounter [[Spain|Spanish]] [[slavery|slavers]].<ref name="Reséndez">{{cite book | last = Reséndez | first = Andrés | title = A land so strange: the epic journey of Cabeza de Vaca: the extraordinary tale of a shipwrecked Spaniard who walked across America in the sixteenth century | publisher = Basic Books | year = 2007 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1531 – [[Diego de Ordaz]] ascends the Orinoco to the Atures rapids, just past its confluence with the [[Meta River|Meta]].<ref name=Goodman/> *1532–33 – Pizarro explores and conquers inland to [[Cajamarca]] and [[Cuzco]].<ref name=Goodman>{{cite book | last = Goodman | first = Edward J. | title = The Explorers of South America | publisher = University of Oklahoma Press | year = 1992 | location = Norman | url = }}</ref> *1533 – [[Fortún Ximénez]] finds the tip of [[Baja California]].<ref name=Hayes2007>{{cite book | last = Hayes | first = Derek | title = Historical Atlas of California | publisher = University of California Press | year = 2007 | location = | page = }}</ref> *1534 – [[Jacques Cartier]] explores the [[Gulf of St. Lawrence]], discovering [[Anticosti Island]] and [[Prince Edward Island]].<ref name=Morison/> *1535 – [[Fray Tomás de Berlanga]] discovers the [[Galapagos Islands]].<ref>Markham, Clements R. ''Discovery of the Galapagos Islands'' (Proceedings of the Royal Geographical Society, Vol. XIV, May 1892, pp. 314–16).</ref> *1535 – Cartier ascends "La Grande Rivière" or "La Rivière de Hochelaga" (the [[St. Lawrence River]]) to the village of [[Hochelaga (village)|Hochelaga]] (present-day [[Montreal]]).<ref name=Morison/> *1535–37 – Diego de Almagro leads en expedition from Cuzco to the south, taking the [[Inca road system|Inca highway]] to the southwest shore of [[Lake Titicaca]], through the [[altiplano]] and the [[Salta Province|Salta valley]] to [[Copiapó Province|Copiapó]]; a detachment continues south to the [[Maule River]]. Almagro takes the coastal route back, through the [[Atacama Desert]].<ref name=Goodman/> *1539 – [[Francisco de Ulloa]] sails to the head of the [[Gulf of California]] and around Baja California to [[Cedros Island]], establishing that Baja is a peninsula.<ref name=Hayes2007/> *1539–43 – [[Hernando de Soto]]'s expedition explores much of the modern [[Southern United States|American South]], becoming the first to cross the [[Appalachian Mountains|Appalachian]]s (over the [[Blue Ridge Mountain]]s) and the Mississippi.<ref name=Morison1974/><ref name=Hayes/> *1540–42 – [[Francisco Vásquez de Coronado]] searches for the mythical [[Seven Cities of Cibola]], only to find [[Zuni-Cibola Complex|villages of mud and thatch]]. He sends out smaller parties, one of which, under [[García López de Cárdenas]], discovers the [[Grand Canyon]]; another finds a city of [[gold]] called [[Quivira]] (in modern [[Kansas]]), which Coronado later visits — although he finds no gold.<ref name=Hayes/> *1540 – [[Hernando de Alarcón]] ascends the [[Colorado River]] to the confluence of the [[Gila River]] (near present-day [[Yuma, Arizona]]).<ref name=Hayes2007/> *1541–42 – [[Francisco de Orellana]] sails down the length of the Amazon.<ref name=Smith>{{cite book | last = Smith | first = Anthony | title = Explorers of the Amazon | publisher = University of Chicago Press | year = 2004 | isbn = 0-226-76337-4 | page = }}</ref> *1542–43 – [[Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo]] explores the coasts of modern Baja and [[California]] from Punta Baja to the [[Russian River (California)|Russian River]], discovering the [[Channel Islands of California|Channel Islands]]; after his death, his second-in-command, [[Bartolomé Ferrer]], reaches [[Point Arena, California|Point Arena]].<ref name=Kelsey>{{cite book | last = Kelsey | first = Harry | title = Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo | publisher = The Huntington Library | year = 1986 | location = San Marino | page = }}</ref> *1542 or 1543 – [[Fernão Mendes Pinto]], [[António Mota]] and Francisco Zeimoto reach [[Tanegashima]], [[Japan]].<ref name=Diffie/> *1543 – [[Ruy López de Villalobos]] discovers three islands ([[Fais Island|Fais]], [[Ulithi]] and [[Yap]]) in the [[Caroline Islands|Caroline]]s and eight atolls ([[Kwajalein Atoll|Kwajalein]], [[Lae Atoll|Lae]], [[Ujae Atoll|Ujae]], [[Wotho Atoll|Wotho]], [[Likiep Atoll|Likiep]], [[Wotje Atoll|Wotje]], [[Erikub Atoll|Erikub]] and [[Maloelap Atoll|Maloelap]]) in the Marshall Islands.<ref name=Quanchi/> *1543 – [[Jean Alfonce]] explores up the [[Saguenay River]], believing it to be "la mer du Cattay".<ref name=Morison/> *1553 – [[Hugh Willoughby]] seeks a [[Northeast Passage]] over [[Russia]]; reaches either [[Kolguyev Island]] or [[Novaya Zemlya]].<ref name=Vaughan/> *1556 – [[Steven Borough]] reaches as far as [[Kara Strait]], between Novaya Zemlya and [[Vaygach Island]].<ref name=Vaughan/> *1557–59 – [[Juan Fernández Ladrillero]] and Cortés Hojea explore the [[Chile]]an coast from [[Valdivia]] (39° 48’ S) to Canal Santa Barbara (54° S); the former passes through the western entrance of the [[Strait of Magellan]] to its eastern entrance and back.<ref name=Morison1974/> *1565 – [[Miguel López de Legazpi]] discovers [[Mejit Island|Mejit]], [[Ailuk Atoll|Ailuk]] and [[Jemo Island|Jemo]] in the Marshall Islands, while his subordinate [[Alonso de Arellano]] discovers [[Lib Island|Lib]] in the same island group, as well as five islands ([[Oroluk Atoll|Oroluk]], [[Chuuk State|Chuuk]], Pulap, [[Sorol]] and [[Ngulu Atoll|Ngulu]]) in the Caroline Islands.<ref name=Quanchi/> *1568 – [[Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira|Álvaro de Mendaña]] discovers the [[Solomon Islands]].<ref name=Whitfield/> *1576 – [[Martin Frobisher]] discovers "Meta Incognita" ("the unknown bourne"; [[Baffin Island]]) and what he believes to be a passage to Cathay: "Frobishers Streytes" ([[Frobisher Bay]]).<ref name=Morison/> *1577–80 – [[Francis Drake|Sir Francis Drake]] completes the second circumnavigation of the globe.<ref name=Bawlf>{{cite book | last = Bawlf | first = Samuel | title = The Secret Voyage of Sir Francis Drake, 1577–1580 | publisher = Walker & Company | year = 2003 | location = | page = }}</ref> *1578 – Frobisher sails part way up the "Mistaken Straites" ([[Hudson Strait]]).<ref name=Morison/> *1581–82 – [[Yermak Timofeyevich]] and his men cross the [[Ural Mountains]] and reach as far as [[Qashliq|Isker]] on the banks of the [[Irtysh River|Irtysh]] (near modern [[Tobolsk]]).<ref name=Lincoln>{{cite book | last = Lincoln | first = W. Bruce | title = The Conquest of a Continent: Siberia and the Russians | publisher = Cornell University Press | year = 2007 | location = Ithaca, N.Y. | page = }}</ref><ref name= Lantzeff>{{cite book | last = Lantzeff | first = George V., and Richard A. Pierce | title = Eastward to Empire: Exploration and Conquest on the Russian Open Frontier, to 1750 | publisher = McGill-Queen's U.P. | year = 1973 | location = Montreal | page = }}</ref> *1585 – [[John Davis (English explorer)|John Davis]] explores [[Davis Strait]], reaching 66°40′ N; also sails up [[Cumberland Sound]], thinking it to be a "passage to Cathay".<ref name=Morison/> *1587 – Davis sails up the west coast of [[Greenland]] as far as 72°46′ N (about modern [[Upernavik]]).<ref name=Morison/> *1589 – [[João da Gama]] reaches "Yezo" ([[Hokkaido]]).<ref>[http://asj.upd.edu.ph/mediabox/archive/ASJ-04-01-1966/texeira-moric-benyovsky-04-01-66.pdf] ''Count Moric Benyovszky: A Hungarian Cruzoe in Asia'', Fr, Manuel Teixeira, page 129</ref> *1592 – Davis discovers the [[Falkland Islands]].<ref name=Markham1889>{{cite book | last = Markham | first = Clements | title = A life of John Davis: the navigator, 1550–1605, discoverer of Davis straits | publisher = Dodd, Mead | year = 1889 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=U_gof0P6PukC&printsec=frontcover&dq=A+life+of+John+Davis&hl=en&ei=Y21UTL35KpKksQPAvezZAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1595 – Mendaña discovers the [[Marquesas Islands|Marquesas]].<ref name=Whitfield/> *1596 – [[Willem Barentsz]] discovers [[Spitsbergen]].<ref name=Conway>{{cite book | last = Conway | first = William Marten | title = No Man's Land: A History of Spitsbergen from Its Discovery in 1596 to the Beginning of the Scientific Exploration of the Country | publisher = University Press | year = 1906 | location = Cambridge | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=j8AEAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA146&dq=No+Man's+Land+Spitsbergen&hl=en&ei=pm1UTJzMFI34swP6oInaAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
==17th century==
[[File:Last Voyage Of Henry Hudson.jpg|thumb|right|[[John Collier (Pre-Raphaelite painter)|John Collier]]'s painting of Henry Hudson cast adrift.]] [[File:Krsk koch.JPG|thumb|right|A 17th-century [[Koch (boat)|koch]] in a museum in [[Krasnoyarsk]]. Kochi were used to explore the [[Siberia]]n watershed and coasts by men such as Kurochkin, Perfilyev and Dezhnev.]] [[File:Gilsemans 1642.jpg|thumb|"Murderers' Bay", on the South Island of New Zealand, where several of Tasman's men were killed by Maori in December 1642.]] [[File:Клавдий В. Лебедев - Экспедиция Семёна Дежнёва.jpg|thumb|''The expedition of Semyon Dezhnyov'' by [[Klavdy Lebedev]]]] [[File:Pere Marquette.JPG|thumb|''Pere Marquette and the Indians'' at the Mississippi River, oil painting (1869) by [[Wilhelm Lamprecht]] (1838–1906), at [[Marquette University]].]]
*1600–01 – Prince Miron Shakhovskoi and D. Khripunov descend the [[Ob River|Ob]] to the [[Gulf of Ob|Ob Estuary]] and ascend the [[Taz River]], establishing the [[Ostrog (fortress)|ostrog]] of [[Mangazeya]] about {{convert|161|km|mi}} to {{convert|240|km|mi}} from its mouth.<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=Forsyth>{{cite book | last = Forsyth | first = James | title = A History of the Peoples of Siberia: Russia's North Asian colony 1581–1990 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 1992 | location = Cambridge | page = }}</ref> *1602–06 – [[Bento de Góis]] travels overland from India to China, via [[Afghanistan]] and the [[Pamirs]].<ref name=Wessels>{{cite book | last = Wessels | first = C. | title = Early Jesuit travellers in Central Asia: 1603–1721 | publisher = Asian Educational Services | year = 1992 | isbn = 81-206-0741-4 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=EXt95lmbRdoC&lpg=1 | page = 90}}</ref> *1605 – [[Ket River|Ketsk]] serving men ascend the [[Ket River|Ket]], portage to the [[Yenisei River|Yenisei]], and descend it to its confluence with the [[Sym River|Sym]].<ref name=Fisher1943/> *1606 – [[Willem Janszoon]] discovers [[Australia]] at the mouth of the [[Pennefather River]] on the western coast of the [[Cape York Peninsula]], exploring its coast from [[Badu Island]] south to Cape Keerweer (13°58′ S).<ref name=Mutch/> *1606 – [[Pedro Fernandes de Queirós]] discovers [[Espiritu Santo]], the largest island in what is now the nation of [[Vanuatu]].<ref name=Mutch/> *1606 – [[Luís Vaz de Torres]] sails through [[Torres Strait|the strait]] that now bears his name.<ref name=Mutch>{{cite book | last =Mutch | first =T. D. | authorlink = | title =The First Discovery of Australia | publisher =Mutch, [[Project Gutenberg of Australia]] | year =1942 | location =Sydney | page =55 | url =http://gutenberg.net.au/ebooks06/0600631h.html}}</ref> *1607 – Mangazeyan ''[[promyshlenniki]]'' and traders reach the lower [[Yenisei River|Yenisei]], establish [[Turukhansk]], and ascend the [[Nizhnyaya Tunguska|Lower Tunguska]], while Ketsk serving men ascend the Yenisei to the [[Angara River|Angara]], which they also ascend.<ref name=Fisher1943>{{cite book | last = Fisher | first = Raymond Henry | title = The Russian Fur Trade, 1550–1700 | publisher = University of California Press | year = 1943 | location = | page = }}</ref> *1607 – [[Henry Hudson]] coasts the east coast of Greenland, naming "Hold-with-Hope" (around 73° N).<ref name=Asher>{{cite book | last = Asher | first = Georg Michael | title = Henry Hudson: The Navigator | publisher = Hakluyt Society | year = 1860 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=IwcVAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Henry+Hudson+the+navigator&hl=en&ei=zWxUTN26JY30swPPzqTZAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1609 – Hudson sails the ''Halve Maen'' up the [[Hudson River]] as fall north as present day [[Albany, New York]].<ref name=Hunter>{{cite book | last = Hunter | first = Douglas | title = Half Moon: Henry Hudson and the voyage that redrew the map of the New World | publisher = Bloomsbury Press | year = 2009 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1610 – [[Étienne Brûlé]] ascends the [[Ottawa River]] and reaches [[Lake Nipissing]] and [[Georgian Bay]] in [[Lake Huron]].<ref name=Butterfield>{{cite book | last = Butterfield | first = Consul Willshire | title = History of Brulé's discoveries and explorations, 1610–1626: being a narrative of the discovery, by Stephen Brulé of Lakes Huron, Ontario and Superior : and of his exploration (the first made by civilized man) of Pennsylvania and western New York, also of the province of Ontario, Canada | publisher = Helman-Taylor | year = 1898 | location = Cleveland | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=yBcuAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+Brul%C3%A9's+Discoveries+and+Explorations,+1610%E2%80%931626&hl=en&ei=5gt0TMOYAo7AsAPe2rzECA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1610 – Kondratiy Kurochkin leads an expedition, sailing in [[Koch (boat)|kochi]], from Turukhansk to the mouth of the [[Yenisei River|Yenisei]] and east to the mouth of the [[Pyasina River|Pyasina]] on the [[Taymyr Peninsula]].<ref name=Vaughan/><ref name=Lantzeff/> *1610 – A detachment from Mangazeya ascends the Yenisei a further {{convert|640|km|mi}} to its confluence with the [[Sym River|Sym]].<ref name=Fisher1943/> *1610–11 – Hudson sails through [[Hudson Strait]] into [[Hudson Bay]], where he overwinters in [[James Bay]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Mancall | first = Peter | title = The Fatal Journey: The Final Expedition of Henry Hudson | publisher = Basic Books | year = 2009 | location = | pages = }}</ref> *1611 – Mangazeyan men reach the [[Khatanga River|Khatanga]].<ref name=Armstrong2010>{{cite book | last = Armstrong | first = Terence | title = Russian Settlement in the North | publisher = Cambridge University Press | year = 2010 | isbn = | url = | page = }}</ref> *1612–13 – [[Thomas Button]] is the first to explore the western shores of [[Hudson Bay]], where he winters in the mouth of the [[Nelson River]]; also discovers [[Coats Island|Coats]] and [[Southampton Island]]s.<ref name=Christy/> *1614 – [[History of whaling|Whalers]] discover [[Jan Mayen]].<ref name=Hacq>Hacquebord, Louwrens (2004). "The Jan Mayen Whaling Industry" in ''Jan Mayen Island in Scientific Focus'', Stig Skreslet, editor, Springer Verlag.</ref> *1615–16 – Étienne Brûlé sights the western shore of [[Lake Ontario]], descends the [[Niagara River]], explores what are now parts of modern [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Pennsylvania]], and descends the [[Susquehanna River]] to [[Chesapeake Bay]].<ref name=Butterfield/> *1616 – [[Jacob Le Maire]] and [[Willem Schouten]] discover and name [[Le Maire Strait]], [[Isla de los Estados|Staten Island]], and [[Cape Horn]]; also discover [[Tonga]] ([[Niuafo'ou]], [[Niuatoputapu]], and [[Tafahi]]), [[Futuna Island, Wallis and Futuna|Futuna]] and [[Alofi]] (in modern [[Wallis and Futuna]]), and several islands in the [[Tuamotu Archipelago|Tuamotu]] ([[Takaroa]], [[Takapoto]], [[Manihi]], [[Ahe]] and [[Rangiroa]]) and [[Bismarck Archipelago]]s (including [[New Hanover Island|New Hanover]] and [[New Ireland (island)|New Ireland]]).<ref name=Morison1974/><ref name=Quanchi/> *1616 – [[Robert Bylot]] and [[William Baffin]] reach 77°30′ N, enter [[Baffin Bay]], discover [[Smith Sound|Smith]], [[Jones Sound|Jones]], and [[Lancaster Sound]]s and sight the coasts of [[Ellesmere Island|Ellesmere]], [[Devon Island|Devon]], and [[Bylot Island]]s.<ref name=Markham>{{cite book | last = Markham | first = Clements | title = The voyages of William Baffin, 1612–1622 | publisher = Hakluyt Society | year = 1881 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pmcMAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=William+Baffin&hl=en&ei=iGxUTJDPKZKcsQOzy_3ZAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1616 – [[Dirk Hartog]] explores some {{convert|576|km|mi}} of coastline (the coast of [[Western Australia]] from about 22° to 28° S), discovering [[Dirk Hartog Island]] and [[Shark Bay]].<ref name=Wood>{{cite book | last = Wood | first = George Arnold | title = The discovery of Australia | publisher = Macmillan & Company | year = 1922 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lHnOAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1617 – [[England|English]] [[walrus]] hunters sight the southern coast of "Sir Thomas Smith's Island" ([[Nordaustlandet]]).<ref name=Conway/> *1618 – [[Pedro Páez]] is believed to be the first European to see and describe the source of the [[Blue Nile]] in Ethiopia.<ref name=Budge>{{cite book | last = Budge | first = E.A. Wallis | authorlink = E. A. Wallis Budge | title = A History of Ethiopia: Nubia and Abyssinia, 1928 | publisher = Oosterhout: Anthropological Publications | year = 1970 | location = | url = }}</ref> *1618 – [[Lenaert Jacobszoon]] discovers an "island" at 22° S (the coast of Western Australia from [[Point Cloates]] to [[North West Cape]]).<ref name=Mutch/> *1619 – [[Frederick de Houtman]] sights the coast of Western Australia near [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]] and sails along the coast north for over {{convert|640|km|mi}}.<ref name=Mutch/> *1620 – Mangazeyan serving men reach the [[Vilyuy River]] and descend it to its confluence with the [[Lena River|Lena]].<ref name=Fisher1943/> *1621–23 – Étienne Brûlé and his companion Grenolle travel along the [[North Channel (Ontario)|North Channel]] of Lake Huron (probably sighting [[Manitoulin Island]]) to "Grand Lac" ([[Lake Superior]]) via [[St. Marys River (Michigan–Ontario)|St. Mary's River]].<ref name=Butterfield/> *1622 – The [[Netherlands|Dutch]] ship ''Leeuwin'' discovers land near present-day [[Cape Leeuwin]].<ref name=Wood/> *1623 – [[Jan Carstenszoon]] discovers the western coast of Cape York Peninsula from Cape Keerweer to the southern mouth of the [[Gilbert-Einasleigh River|Gilbert River]]; while his consort '''Willem Joosten van Colster''' discovers "Arnhemsland" and "Speultsland" (modern [[Arnhem Land]] and perhaps [[Groote Eylandt]]).<ref name=Wood/><ref name=Peters>{{cite book | last = Peters | first = Nonja | title = The Dutch down under, 1606–2006. | publisher = University of Western Australia Press | year = 2006 | location = Crawley, W.A.}}</ref> *1624 – [[António de Andrade]] crosses the [[Himalayas]] through the [[Mana Pass]] and reaches [[Tibet]].<ref name=Wessels/> *1627 – [[Jesuit]] missionaries [[Estêvão Cacella]] and [[João Cabral]] cross the [[Himalayas]] and are the first to enter [[Bhutan]].<ref name=Wessels/><ref name=Kapadia>{{cite book | last = Kapadia | first = Harish | title = Into the untravelled Himalaya: travels, treks, and climbs | publisher = Indus Publishing | year = 2005 | isbn = 81-7387-181-7 | page = 72}}</ref> *1627 – [[François Thijssen]], accompanied by [[Pieter Nuyts]], discovers over {{convert|1609|km|mi}} of coastline east of [[Cape Leeuwin]] to the eastern end of the [[Great Australian Bight]].<ref name=Mutch/> *1628 – Cabral is the first to enter [[Nepal]].<ref name=Wessels/> *1628 – Gerrit Frederikszoon de Witt captain of the [[Vianen (ship)|''Vianen'']] discovers "Witsland" about 21° S, sailing {{convert|320|km|mi}} along the coast and discovering [[Barrow Island (Western Australia)|Barrow Island]] and parts of the [[Dampier Archipelago]].<ref name=Wood/> *1628–30 – Vasilii Bugor ascends the [[Upper Tunguska]] and portages to the upper Lena, descending it to its confluence with the [[Kirenga River|Kirenga]].<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=Fisher1943/> *1631–32 – [[Luke Foxe]] and [[Thomas James (sea captain)|Thomas James]], in separate expeditions, both circumnavigate Hudson Bay in search of a Northwest Passage; Foxe sails through [[Foxe Channel|the channel]] and into [[Foxe Basin|the basin]] now named after him to 66°47′ N, while James winters in the bay [[James Bay|named after him]].<ref name=Christy>{{cite book | last = Christy | first = Miller | title = The voyages of Captain Luke Foxe of Hull, and Captain Thomas James of Bristol, in search of a northwest passage, in 1631–32; with narratives of the earlier northwest voyages of Frobisher, Davis, Weymouth, Hall, Knight, Hudson, Button, Gibbons, Bylot, Baffin, Hawkridge, and others | publisher = Hakluyt Society | year = 1894 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Vh87AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=related:STANFORD36105004846502#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1632–33 – [[Pyotr Beketov]] descends the Lena as far as its great bend, erects the ostrog [[Yakutsk]], and sends a detachment some {{convert|720|km|mi}} downriver (where the ''zimovie'' [[Zhigansky District|Zhigansk]] is built) and another east up the [[Aldan River|Aldan]] as far as the [[Amga River|Amga]] (which they also ascend in search of [[yasak]]).<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=Forsyth/> *1633–34 – [[Jean Nicolet]] discovers [[Lake Michigan]] and likely reaches [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]].<ref name=Fischer>{{cite book | last = Fischer | first = David Hackett | title = Champlain's Dream: The European Founding of North America. | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 2008 | location = New York}}</ref> *1633–38 – [[Ilya Perfilyev]] and Ivan Rebrov sail from Zhigansk in kochi some {{convert|800|km|mi}} downriver to the mouth of the Lena and sail along the coast east and west, reaching the mouths of the [[Olenyok River|Olenyok]], [[Yana River|Yana]], and [[Indigirka River|Indigirka]] rivers.<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March>{{cite book | last = March | first = G. Patrick | title = Eastern destiny: Russia in Asia and the North Pacific | publisher = Praeger | year = 1996 | location = Westport, Conn | page = }}</ref> *1638–40 – Poznik Ivanov crosses the [[Verkhoyansk Range]] into the upper reaches of the Yana, and then portages over the [[Chersky Range]] into the Indigirka River system.<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March/> *1639–40 – [[Maksim Perfilyev]] ascends the [[Vitim River]] to the [[Tsipa River|Tsipa]], which he also ascends (until rapids force him to turn back), becoming the first Russian to enter [[Transbaikal]].<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1639–41 – [[Ivan Moskvitin]] ascends the [[Maya River|Maya]], portages across the [[Dzhugdzhur Mountains]], and descends the [[Ulya River|Ulya]] to the [[Sea of Okhotsk]]; two groups are sent to the north and south, reaching the mouths of the [[Taui Bay|Taui]] and [[Uda River (Khabarovsk Krai)|Uda]] rivers, respectively.<ref name=Lincoln/><ref name=Lantzeff/> *1641 – Dmitri Zyrian discovers the [[Alazeya River|Alazeya]], which he ascends as far as the [[tree line]].<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1642–43 – [[Abel Tasman]] discovers "Anthony van Diemenslandt" ([[Tasmania]]) and "Staten Landt" ([[New Zealand]]); following year discovers "'t Eylandt Amsterdam" ([[Tongatapu]]), [[Fiji]] and [[New Britain]].<ref name=Quanchi/><ref name=Wood/> *1643 – [[Kurbat Ivanov]] reaches the western shores of [[Lake Baikal]], opposite [[Olkhon]].<ref name=Haywood>{{cite book | last = Haywood | first = A. J. | title = Siberia: a cultural history | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2010 | location = Oxford | page = }}</ref> *1643 – [[Maarten Gerritsz Vries]] sails along the eastern coast of "Yezo" ([[Hokkaidō]]), between [[Iturup]] and [[Urup]], to [[Sakhalin]].<ref name=Whitfield/> *1643 – Vasiliy Sychev discovers the [[Anabar River|Anabar]], where he establishes the ''zimovie'' Anabarskoye.<ref name=Armstrong2010/><ref name=Holland>{{cite book | last = Holland | first = Clive | title = Arctic Exploration and Development, c. 500 B.C. to 1915: an encyclopedia | publisher = Garland | year = 1994 | location = New York | url = | page = }}</ref> *1643–45 – [[Vassili Poyarkov]] crosses the [[Stanovoy Range]] and descends the [[Zeya River|Zeya]] to the [[Amur River|Amur]], which he follows to its mouth; from here, he coasts along the Sea of Okhotsk to the Ulya (on the way sighting the [[Shantar Islands]]).<ref name=Golder>{{cite book | last = Golder | first = Frank Alfred | title = Russian expansion on the Pacific, 1641–1850 an account of the earliest and later expeditions made by the Russians along the Pacific coast of Asia and North America; including some related expeditions to the Arctic regions | publisher = Authur H. Clark Co. | year = 1914 | location = Cleveland | page = }}</ref> *1644 – Tasman maps the northern coast of Australia, connecting "Nova Guinea" (the Cape York Peninsula) with "the land of D'Eendracht" (Western Australia).<ref name=Wood/> *1644 – [[Mikhail Stadukhin]] reaches the [[Kolyma River|Kolyma]].<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1644–47 – Ivan Pokhabov is the first to ascend the Angara to Lake Baikal, which he crosses to the [[Selenga River|Selenga]]; he later ascends it and reaches [[Ulaanbaatar|Urga]] (in present-day [[Mongolia]]).<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=Forsyth/> *1646 – Isaya Ignatyev reaches [[Chaunskaya Bay]].<ref name=Vaughan>{{cite book | last = Vaughan | first = Richard | title = The Arctic: A History | publisher = A. Sutton | year = 2007 | location = Stroud | page = }}</ref> *1648–49 – [[Semyon Dezhnyov]] sails from the Kolyma, rounds [[Cape Dezhnev]] (thus proving Asia and America are separate), and reaches the [[Anadyr River]], which he ascends for some {{convert|563|km|mi}} (here he builds the ''zimovie'' [[Anadyrsk]]).<ref name=Lincoln/> *1649–51 – [[Yerofey Khabarov]] ascends the [[Olyokma River]], crosses the northern [[Yablonoi Mountains]], and descends the Amur to its confluence with the [[Songhua River|Songhua]].<ref name=Lincoln/><ref name=Golder/> *1650 – Stadukhin and Semen Motora travel from the Kolyma, across the Anyuyskiy Range, to Anadyrsk.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1651–57 – Stadukhin travels from Anadyrsk to the mouth of the [[Penzhina Bay|Penzhina River]], then west along the northern coast of the Sea of Okhotsk to [[Okhotsk]].<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March/> *1653–54 – Beketov ascends the [[Khilok River|Khilok]], crosses the southern Yablonoi Mountains, and descends the [[Ingoda River|Ingoda]] and [[Shilka River|Shilka]] rivers to the latter's confluence with the [[Nercha River|Nercha]] (where his men build the ostrog [[Nerchinsk]]).<ref name=Lantzeff/> *1654 – [[Médard Chouart des Groseilliers]] explores the entire western shore of Lake Michigan.<ref name=DeVoto/> *1659 – Groseilliers and [[Pierre-Esprit Radisson]] explore the southern shore of Lake Superior as far west as [[Chequamegon Bay]].<ref name=DeVoto/> *1661 – [[Johann Grueber]] and [[Albert Dorville]] are the first to visit [[Lhasa]].<ref name=Sandberg>{{cite book | last = Sandberg | first = Graham | title = The Exploration of Tibet, its history and particulars from 1623 to 1904 | publisher = Thacker, Spink & Co. | year = 1904 | location = Calcutta | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=OgRxAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA15&dq=European+exploration+Tibet&hl=en&ei=5U-2TM_VMpCssAOLn_TDCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1669 – [[René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle|Robert de la Salle]] discovers the [[Ohio River|Ohio]], descending it as far as the [[Falls of the Ohio National Wildlife Conservation Area|Falls of Ohio]] at the site of modern [[Louisville, Kentucky]].<ref name=Parkman/> *1673 – [[Louis Jolliet]] and [[Jacques Marquette]] reach the upper Mississippi, descending it to its confluence with the [[Arkansas River|Arkansas]]; also discover the [[Missouri River|Missouri]].<ref name=Parkman/> *1675 – [[Anthony de la Roché]] discovers [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} *1682 – Robert de La Salle descends the "Rivière de Colbert" ([[Mississippi River|Mississippi]]) to its mouth.<ref name=Parkman>{{cite book | last = Parkman | first = Francis | title = La Salle and the Discovery of the Great West | publisher = The Modern Library | year = 1999 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1688–89 – [[Jacques de Noyon]] discovers [[Rainy Lake]] and [[Lake of the Woods]].<ref name=DeVoto/> *1690–92 – [[Henry Kelsey]] travels from [[York Factory, Manitoba|York Factory]] southwestward, probably reaching the [[Saskatchewan River|Saskatchewan]] and the headwaters of the [[Assiniboine River|Assiniboine]]—in the process becoming the first European to see the [[Canadian Prairies]].<ref name=DeVoto/> *1696 – [[Luka Morozko]] travels almost halfway down the west coast of [[Kamchatka Peninsula|Kamchatka]], reaching the [[Tigil River]].<ref name=March/> *1697–99 – [[Vladimir Atlasov]] reaches as far as the [[Golygina River]] on the southwest coast of Kamchatka, from which he sights [[Atlasov Island]]; also crosses the [[Sredinny Range]] (twice), reaching [[Olyutorsky Gulf]] and the [[Kamchatka River]].<ref name=Lantzeff/><ref name=March/>
==18th century== [[File:Cook new zealand.jpg|thumb|Cook's map of New Zealand]] [[File:Hodges, Resolution and Adventure in Matavai Bay.jpg|thumb|''[[HMS Resolution (Cook)|Resolution]] and [[HMS Adventure (1771)|Adventure]] in Matavai Bay'' by [[William Hodges]]]] [[File:Vancouver-Rainier.jpg|thumb|"Mount Rainier from the south Part of Admiralty Inlet". The mountain was discovered by Vancouver during his exploration of Puget Sound in the spring of 1792.]] [[File:Alex MacKenzie from Canada by land.jpg|thumb|300px|Inscription at the end of the Alexander Mackenzie's Canada crossing located at {{coord|52|22|43|N|127|28|14|W}}]]
*1706 – Mikhail Nasedkin reaches [[Cape Lopatka]] and sights [[Shumshu]], northernmost of the [[Kuril Islands]].<ref name=March/> *1710 – [[Yakov Permyakov]] discovers [[Bolshoy Lyakhovsky Island]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} *1713 – Ivan Kozyrevsky reaches Shumshu and [[Paramushir]].<ref name=March/> *1714 – [[Étienne de Veniard, Sieur de Bourgmont]] ascends the Missouri as far as the [[Platte River|Platte]], becoming the first to enter the present-day [[Nebraska]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1720 – Pedro de Villasur travels from Santa Fe, through what is now part of southeastern [[Colorado]], to the lower Platte in eastern Nebraska.<ref name=Hayes/> *1722 – [[Jakob Roggeveen]] discovers "Paasch Eiland" ([[Easter Island]]) and [[Tutuila]] and [[Upolu]].<ref name=Fischer2005>{{cite book | last = Fischer | first = Steven R. | title = Island at the End of the World: the Turbulent History of Easter Island | publisher = Reaktion | year = 2005 | location = London | url = }}</ref><ref name=Tcherkezoff>{{cite book | last = Tcherkezoff | first = Serge | title = First contacts in Polynesia: the Samoan case (1722–1848) : western misunderstanding about sexuality and divinity | publisher = ANUE Press | year = 2008 | location = Canberra | url = }}</ref> *1728 – [[Vitus Bering]] sails through the strait that now bears his name; also discovers and names [[Saint Lawrence Island]].<ref name=Vaughan/> *1732 – [[Mikhail Gvozdev]] discovers the "Large Country" ([[Alaska]]).<ref name=Golder/> *1734 – [[Jean Baptiste de La Vérendrye]] discovers [[Lake Winnipeg]].<ref name=DeVoto>{{cite book | last = DeVoto | first = Bernard | title = The Course of Empire | publisher = Houghton Mifflin | year = 1980 | location = Boston | page = }}</ref> *1734–37 – Stepan Muravev and Mikhail Pavlov chart the Russian coast from [[Arkhangelsk]] to just east of the [[Pechora River|Pechora]], while [[Stepan Malygin]] charts it from there to the Ob River, including the [[Yamal Peninsula]].<ref name=Lincoln/> *1735–36 – [[Vasili Pronchishchev]] charts the Russian coast from the Lena west to the [[Khatanga River|Khatanga]].<ref name=Lincoln/> *1737 – [[Dmitry Ovtsyn]] charts the Russian coast from the mouth of the Ob to the Yenisei.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1738 – [[Pierre Gaultier de Varennes, sieur de La Vérendrye|Pierre de La Vérendrye]] visits [[Mandan]] villages near the site of present-day [[Bismarck, North Dakota]].<ref name=Parkman1893>{{cite book | last = Parkman | first = Francis | title = France and England in North America: A Series of Historical Narratives | publisher = Little, Brown | year = 1893 | location = Boston | url = }}</ref> *1738–40 – [[Fyodor Minin]] charts the Russian coast from the Yenisei to the Pyasina.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1739 – [[Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier|Jean Bouvet de Lozier]] discovers "Cape Circumcision" ([[Bouvet Island]]).<ref name=Mills/> *1739–41 – [[Dmitry Laptev]] charts the Russian coast from the Lena to just east of the Kolyma.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1741 – Bering sights [[Mount Saint Elias|Mount St. Elias]], the entrance of [[Prince William Sound]], the [[Alaska Peninsula]] (from Cape Providence to Chignik Bay) and several of the [[Aleutian Islands]] (discovering [[Great Sitkin Island|Great Sitkin]], [[Atka Island|Atka]], and [[Kiska]]), as well as discovering [[Kayak Island|Kayak]], [[Montague Island (Alaska)|Montague]], [[Hinchinbrook Island (Alaska)|Hinchinbrook]], [[Sitkalidak Island|Sitkalidak]], and the [[Shumagin Islands|Shumagin]] and [[Commander Islands]]; his second-in-command, [[Aleksei Chirikov]], sights [[Mount Fairweather|Mounts Fairweather]] and [[Mount Douglas (Alaska)|Douglas]] and discovers Noyes and [[Baker Island (Alaska)|Baker Island]]s (both off the west coast of [[Prince of Wales Island (Alaska)|Prince of Wales Island]]), as well as [[Baranof Island|Baranof]], [[Chichagof Island|Chichagof]], [[Kruzof Island|Kruzof]], [[Yakobi Island|Yakobi]], [[Kodiak Island|Kodiak]], [[Afognak]], the Aleutian Islands ([[Umnak]], [[Adak Island|Adak]], [[Agattu]], [[Attu Island|Attu]], and the [[Islands of Four Mountains]]), and the [[Kenai Peninsula]].<ref name=Golder1922>{{cite book | last = Golder | first = Frank Alfred and Leonhard Stejneger | title = Bering’s voyages: an account of the efforts of the Russians to determine the relation of Asia and America | publisher = American Geographical Society | year = 1922 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7P0HAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA36-IA2&dq=bering+1741+voyage&hl=en&ei=cG0BTYGNIIinnAfDv-HlDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1741–42 – [[Khariton Laptev]] and [[Semion Chelyuskin]] chart the [[Taymyr Peninsula]], with the latter reaching [[Cape Chelyuskin]], the northernmost point of Asia.<ref name=Lincoln/> *1742 – [[Christopher Middleton (navigator)|Christopher Middleton]] discovers [[Wager Bay]] and [[Repulse Bay, Nunavut|Repulse Bay]].<ref name=Williams2003>{{cite book | last = Williams | first = Glyndwr | title = Voyages of delusion: the quest for the Northwest Passage | publisher = Yale University Press | year = 2003 | location = New Haven | page = }}</ref> *1742–43 – [[Louis-Joseph Gaultier de La Vérendrye]] and his brother [[François de La Vérendrye|François]] reach the [[Big Horn Mountains]] of modern [[Wyoming]]; on their return they reach the vicinity of present-day [[Pierre, South Dakota]].<ref name=Parkman1893/><ref>Champagne, Father Antoine. The Vérendryes and Their Succossors, 1727–1760 (MHS Transactions, Series 3, No. 25, 1968–69 Season).</ref> *1747 – Jeremiah Westall discovers [[Chesterfield Inlet]] and sails about sixty miles up it.<ref name=Williams2003/> *1761–62 – William Christopher sails {{convert|370|km|mi}} into Chesterfield Inlet to the western end of [[Baker Lake, Nunavut|Baker Lake]].<ref name=Williams2003/> *1767 – [[Samuel Wallis]] discovers "King George's Land" ([[Tahiti]]).<ref name=Hough>{{cite book | last = Hough | first = Richard | title = Captain James Cook: a biography | publisher = Norton | year = 1994 | location = New York | page = }}</ref> *1769 – José Ortega discovers [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref name=Hayes2007/> *1769–70 – [[James Cook]] circumnavigates both islands of New Zealand, proving they aren't part of [[Terra Australis Incognita]]; also discovers the east coast of Australia from [[Cape Howe]] to [[Cape York Peninsula|Cape York]].<ref name=Hough/> *1771–72 – [[Samuel Hearne]] reaches the [[Coppermine River|Coppermine]], descending it to what would become known as [[Coronation Gulf]]; the following year, on his way back, he becomes the first to sight and cross [[Great Slave Lake]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1772 – [[Yves-Joseph de Kerguelen-Trémarec]] discovers the [[Kerguelen Islands]].<ref name=Mills/> *1772 – [[Pedro Fages]] sights the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Farquhar |first=Francis P. |title=History of the Sierra Nevada |publisher=University of California Press |year=2007 |page= |isbn=0-520-25395-7}}</ref> *1773 – [[Ivan Lyakhov]] reaches [[Kotelny Island]].<ref name=Vaughan/> *1773–75 – Cook is the first to cross the [[Antarctic Circle]], reaching 71° 10’ S, thus finally disproving the existence of Terra Australis Incognita; also discovers [[New Caledonia]] and the [[South Sandwich Islands]].<ref name=Hough/> *1774 – [[Juan José Pérez Hernández]] explores the western coast of [[North America]] from [[Cape Mendocino]] northwards, discovering the [[Queen Charlotte Islands]], [[Vancouver Island]], and [[Dall Island]].<ref name=Hayes2001>{{cite book | last = Hayes | first = Derek | title = Historical atlas of the North Pacific Ocean: maps of discovery and scientific exploration, 1500–2000 | publisher = Douglas & McIntyre | year = 2001 | location = Vancouver | url = }}</ref> *1775 – [[Bruno de Heceta]] discovers the mouth of the [[Columbia River]]; his consort [[Juan Francisco de la Bodega y Quadra]] discovers [[Prince of Wales Island (Alaska)|Prince of Wales Island]] ([[Bucareli Bay]]).<ref name=Hayes1999>{{cite book | last = Hayes | first = Derek | title = Historical atlas of the Pacific Northwest: Maps of exploration and discovery; British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, Alaska, Yukon | publisher = Sasquatch Books | year = 1999 | location = Seattle | url = }}</ref> *1776 – [[Francisco Atanasio Domínguez]] and [[Silvestre Vélez de Escalante]] follow the Rio Grande north to the modern state of [[Colorado]], where they travel west, discovering [[Utah Lake]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1777–78 – Cook discovers [[Kiritimati|Christmas Island]] and [[Hawaii]]; also explores the Alaskan coast as far north as [[Icy Cape, Alaska|Icy Cape]], discovering [[Cook Inlet]] and [[Prince William Sound]].<ref name=Hough/> *1787 – [[Charles William Barkley]] discovers the [[Strait of Juan de Fuca]].<ref name=Williams2003/> *1788 – [[Captain Arthur Phillip]] arrives with [[The First Fleet]] in [[Botany Bay]] on the coast of [[Sydney, Australia]]. *1789 – [[Alexander Mackenzie (explorer)|Alexander Mackenzie]] descends the [[Mackenzie River]] to its mouth in the [[Arctic Ocean]].<ref name=Mackenzie1801>{{cite book | last = Mackenzie | first = Alexander | title = Voyages from Montreal, on the river St. Lawrence, through the continent of North America, to the Frozen and Pacific oceans; in the years 1789 and 1793 | publisher = T. Cadell, jun. and W. Davies | year = 1801 | location = London | url = }}</ref> *1791 – [[Francisco de Eliza]] discovers the "Canal de Nuestra Señora del Rosario" ([[Strait of Georgia]]); [[José María Narváez]] explores up it, passing the mouth of the [[Fraser River]] and reaching as far north as [[Texada Island]].<ref name=Hayes1999/> *1791–94 – [[George Vancouver]], together with [[William Robert Broughton|William Broughton]], [[Peter Puget]], [[Joseph Whidbey]], and [[James Johnstone (explorer)|James Johnstone]], charts the modern states of [[Oregon]] and [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], the coast of [[British Columbia]], and the [[Alaska Panhandle]], discovering [[Admiralty Island|Admiralty]], [[Mitkof Island|Mitkof]] and [[Wrangell Island]]s in the [[Alexander Archipelago]], as well as proving the insularity of [[Kuiu Island|Kuiu]] and [[Revillagigedo Island]]s; also charts [[Admiralty Inlet]] and [[Puget Sound]] and discovers the [[Chatham Islands]] and [[Snares Islands / Tini Heke|The Snares]].<ref name=Vancouver>{{cite book | last = Vancouver | first = George, and John Vancouver | title = A voyage of discovery to the North Pacific ocean, and round the world | publisher = J. Stockdale | year = 1801; vols. I-VI | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qwol8bPaYxsC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1792 – [[Dionisio Alcalá Galiano]] and [[Cayetano Valdés y Flores]] circumnavigate Vancouver Island, proving its insularity.<ref name=Hayes/> *1792 – [[Jacinto Caamaño]] enters [[Clarence Strait]], showing that much of the Alaska Panhandle is an archipelago, not mainland, as had been presumed; also sights the southwest coast of Revillagigedo Island.<ref name=Hayes/> *1792–93 – Mackenzie ascends the [[Peace River (Canada)|Peace]] and [[Parsnip River|Parsnip]], crosses the [[Canadian Rockies]] to the headwaters of the [[Fraser River|Fraser]], ascends the [[West Road River]] and crosses the [[Coast Mountains]], reaching the [[Bella Coola River|Bella Coola]], which he descends to [[North Bentinck Arm]] and [[Dean Channel]].<ref name=Mackenzie1801/> *1796 – [[Mungo Park (explorer)|Mungo Park]] reaches the upper [[Niger River|Niger]], exploring it from [[Ségou]] to [[Silla, Mali|Silla]].<ref name=Fernandez-Armesto>{{cite book | last = Fernandez-Armesto | first = Felipe | title = Pathfinders: A Global History of Exploration | publisher = W.W. Norton & Company | year = 2006 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1797–98 – [[George Bass]] explores from Cape Howe to [[Western Port]], discovering [[Bass Strait]].<ref name=Wood/> *1798 – [[John Fearn (whaler)|John Fearn]] discovers "Pleasant Island" ([[Nauru]]).<ref name=Quanchi/> *1798 – [[Francisco de Lacerda]] travels from [[Tete, Mozambique|Tete]] northwest to [[Lake Mweru]].<ref name=Jeal1973>{{cite book|last=Jeal|first =Tim|title=Livingstone|publisher = G. P. Putnam’s Sons|year=1973|location=New York|url=}}</ref> *1798–99 – [[Matthew Flinders]] and George Bass circumnavigate Tasmania, proving its insularity.<ref name=Wood/>
==19th century== [[File:Map of Lewis and Clark's Track, Across the Western Portion of North America, published 1814.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The famous map of Lewis and Clark's expedition. It changed mapping of northwest America by providing the first accurate depiction of the relationship of the sources of the [[Columbia River|Columbia]] and [[Missouri River|Missouri]] rivers, and the Rocky Mountains.]] [[File:Descent of Fraser River 1808.jpg|thumb|Colour drawing of Simon Fraser's 1808 descent of the Fraser River.]] [[File:The Crews of H.M.S. Hecla & Griper Cutting Into Winter Harbour, Sept. 26th, 1819.jpg|thumb|"The Crews of H.M.S. Hecla & Griper Cutting Into Winter Harbour, Sept. 26th, 1819". An engraving from the journal published in 1821.]] [[File:Point Turnagain.jpg|thumb|John Franklin's party encamped at Point Turnagain, the furthest point he reached.]] [[File:Nlc hms investigator.jpg|thumb|HMS ''Investigator'', on the northwestern coast of Banks Island, 20 August 1851.]] [[File:McClure Map.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Map drawn by Robert McClure detailing the Northwest Passage, including the 1851 route of the ''Investigator''.]] [[File:Matterhorn ascent Dore.jpg|thumb|upright|The first ascent of the Matterhorn, by [[Gustave Doré]].]] [[File:Fly River Map 1876 NLA.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The original survey map created by L.M. D'Albertis in 1876.]] [[File:Nansen Johansen depart 14 March 1895.jpg|thumb|alt= A group of men pose on the ice with dogs and sledges, with the ship's outline visible in the background|Nansen and Johansen finally depart on their polar journey, 14 March 1895. Nansen is the tall figure, second from left; Johansen is standing second from right.]]
*1800 – [[James Grant (navigator)|James Grant]] discovers the Australian coastline from [[Cape Banks]] to [[Cape Otway]].<ref name=Wood/> *c. 1801–04 – A fur trading post is built on [[Great Bear Lake]].<ref name=Keith>{{cite book | last = Keith | first = Lloyd | title = North of Athabasca: Slave Lake and Mackenzie River documents of the North West Company, 1800–1821 | publisher = McGill-Queen's University Press | year = 2001 | location = Rupert's Land Record Society series. Montreal | url = }}</ref> *1802 – [[John Murray (Australian explorer)|John Murray]] discovers [[Port Phillip Bay]].<ref name=Wood/> *1802 – Matthew Flinders explores the coast from [[Fowlers Bay, South Australia|Fowlers Bay]] to [[Encounter Bay]], discovering [[Spencer Gulf]], [[Kangaroo Island]], and [[Gulf St Vincent|Gulf St. Vincent]].<ref name=Wood/> *1802 – [[Nicolas Baudin]] explores the coast from Cape Banks to Encounter Bay, where he meets Flinders.<ref name=Wood/> *1802–03 – Flinders circumnavigates Australia.<ref name=Wood/> *1805–06 – [[Meriwether Lewis]] and [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]], from [[Fort Mandan]], ascend the Missouri to its headwaters, cross the [[Continental Divide of the Americas|Continental Divide]] via [[Lemhi Pass]] in the [[Bitterroot Range]] to enter the present state of [[Idaho]], and descend the [[Clearwater River (Idaho)|Clearwater]] and [[Snake River|Snake river]]s to the Columbia, which they descend to its mouth; on the way back Lewis explores the [[Blackfoot River (Montana)|Blackfoot]] and [[Sun River|Sun river]]s, as well as the headwaters of the [[Marias River|Marias]], while Clark travels through [[Bozeman Pass]] and descends the [[Yellowstone River|Yellowstone]] to its confluence with the Missouri.<ref name=Ambrose>{{cite book | last = Ambrose | first = Stephen E. | title = Undaunted Courage: Meriwether Lewis, Thomas Jefferson, and the Opening of the American West | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1996 | location = New York | url = }}</ref> *1805–06 – Mungo Park descends the Niger as far as the Bussa rapids, where he is drowned.<ref name=Fernandez-Armesto/> *1806 – [[Yakov Sannikov]] discovers [[New Siberia|New Siberia Island]].<ref name=Mills/> *1806 – [[Abraham Bristow]] discovers the [[Auckland Islands]].<ref name=Mawar/> *1808 – [[Simon Fraser (explorer)|Simon Fraser]] descends the [[Fraser River]] for some {{convert|800|km|mi}} to its mouth, reaching the Strait of Georgia.<ref name=Hayes/> *1810 – [[Frederick Hasselborough]] discovers [[Campbell Island, New Zealand|Campbell]] and [[Macquarie Island]]s.<ref name=Mills/> *1811–12 – [[W. Price Hunt|Wilson Price Hunt]] discovers [[Union Pass]] in the [[Wind River Range]] and reaches the upper Snake River, while [[Robert Stuart (explorer)|Robert Stuart]] discovers [[South Pass (Wyoming)|South Pass]]—his route would later become the [[Oregon Trail]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1816 – [[Otto von Kotzebue]] discovers [[Kotzebue Sound]].<ref name=Hayes/> *1819 – [[William Smith (mariner)|William Smith]] discovers the [[South Shetland Islands]].<ref name=Riffenburgh>{{cite book | last = Riffenburgh | first = Beau | title = Encyclopedia of the Antarctic | publisher = CRC Press | year = 2007 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fRJtB2MNdJMC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=South%20Shetland%20Islands%2C%20Discovery%20of&f=false}}</ref> *1819–20 – [[William Edward Parry]] enters [[Lancaster Sound]] and reaches [[Melville Island (Northwest Territories and Nunavut)|Melville Island]], discovering and naming [[Cornwallis Island (Nunavut)|Cornwallis]], [[Bathurst Island (Canada)|Bathurst]], and [[Somerset Island (Nunavut)|Somerset Island]]s; the following year sights "Banks Land" ([[Banks Island]]).<ref name=Parry>{{cite book | last = Parry | first = William Edward | title = Journal of a voyage for the discovery of a North-West passage from the Atlantic to the Pacific: performed in the years 1819–20 | publisher = John Murray | year = 1821 | location = London | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sdM0AAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=William+Edward+Parry+1819&hl=en&ei=bZ5LTM64M46WsgOW2I1J&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> *1820 – [[Edward Bransfield]] sights the [[Antarctic Peninsula]];
